formatted_address: Golden Horn, Turkey
name: Golden Horn

reviews.text: The Panoramic view overlooking the Golden Horn is Stunning!
Very nice place
Worth visiting
beautiful and historical place

What a historic place. Commercial hub since ages. Many civilizations have thrived here. Hundred of boats and ferries plying their trade from European side to the Asian side. Very peaceful despite thousands of tourists and locals. Cool weather generally on the European side. Visit islands. No. 1.

formatted_address: Binbirdirek, Atmeydanı Cd. No:12, 34122 Fatih/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Museum of Turkish and Islamic Arts

reviews.text: This is a lovely museum in a very nice building. It’s quite specialized and focuses mainly on rugs, pottery/ceramics, books/documents with a few bronzes, sculptures and other artifacts. It wouldn’t be my top choice for a museum visit in Istanbul but it’s a very nice collection, well laid out. There isn’t a lot of information about each object. Unless you are already into Turkish and Islamic art, I may give this one a miss. Although, you can probably see everything in 30-60 minutes.

Really lovely place and glad we visited. We bought the 5 day card deal which works out cheaper. I'm surprised someone reviewed saying it's too much "Islamic art" when it's a museum for that! Haha! But never the less it is lovely and lots of old and beautiful pieces here. For religious or non religious people! VERY clean toilets and Cafe was also not expensive (20TL for a can of coke) would recommend!

Interesting to a extent. Well curated and presented pieces. I was rather hoping for more beautiful Islamic art but it has quite a heavy religious slant. If you are a devout Muslim you may find this especially interesting and possibly even revering. Anyway, it’s a charming location, included in the museum card and has great views of the blue mosque.

A treasure! Beautiful building, lovely and interesting exhibits. Quiet and cool. Kahve in the lavender garden well worth 14l. One of my best Istanbul experiences, out of a lot of very good ones - possibly because after the days of bustle, noise and crowds the tranquility was particularly welcome.
Hands down the best museum I have been to when it comes to Islamic art and history! Amazing pieces are presented transporting you back to this beautiful time in history!

formatted_address: Meşrutiyet, Şair Nigar Sk. 12/A, 34363 Şişli/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Idil Baby

reviews.text: Являемся официальным дистрибьютором данной фабрики! Надежный партнер, рекомендуем к сотрудничеству!
Harika ürünleri var...

formatted_address: Kısıklı, Çamlıca Tepesi, 34692 Üsküdar/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Çamlıca Hill

reviews.text:
Highest point in Çamlıca. Beautiful view over Istanbul. There is a cafe where you can eat, drink and enjoy the beautiful view over Istanbul. Only sad thing is that not only the tourist also the Turkish people leave a lot of waste on the floor. Otherwise it's an awesome place to visit .

A magnificent observation deck from which you can see the whole of Istanbul. In fact, this site is located on a hill in the center of Istanbul. The views are very beautiful.

Very beautiful place! The view here is the best in Istanbul, you can see all Istanbul from here. It's one of the best places to visit is Istanbul! The Cafe's there are very cheap too and the toilets are very clean! 😀
İts very scenic and enjoyable. Only downside is that its very crowded like jam packed. Beautiful views of entire  İstanbul and lots of restaurants. Nice place.
It is an amazing place! You can see İstanbul from there. The restaurant there is very good and the menu’s prices are very good and not expensive at all!!!
A charm place.. Must be visited. Good for families. There is restaurants and WC too. A small park is also there next to it. U can see all istanbul and bosphorus from there

formatted_address: Beylerbeyi, Abdullahağa Cd., 34676 Üsküdar/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Beylerbeyi Palace

reviews.text: Beautiful little palace with great furnishings. A recorder tour is part of the entry fee, which is about 40 lire per person.Nice little cafe is on the grounds where you can enjoy the gardens then you can slip into the palace and take in all the furnishings and decor. Not a must see given Istanbul's plethora of historical sites, but very nice little gem depicting the lives of Sultans

Beautiful palace, built with money borrowed from Europe at a time Turkey's economy was collapsing.
Stunning chandeliers and fine pottery. Lovely tea garden by the duck pond. Shame that several out buildings and the tunnel were closed.
Audio commentary good system.

A beautiful Palace with an astonishing history.
I went with my family to learn some history about turkey and we loved the experience, although taking pictures wasn't permitted which was a bummer however we had a lot of fun, each family member got an ear piece that explains and gives information about every room in the Palace, its a nice and fun outing with the family and would recommend to visit during your stay in Istanbul.

Nice palace but not very old and decorated with west European stuff. It is extrange that sultans that are supposed to help their people did not used the beautiful products manufactured in Turkey. Photographs are not allowed for unknown stupid desitions  of politics with no brain. Far more better stuff could be freely photographed in London, Paris, New York and many other really first class museums. Don't waste your time in this palace.
Excellent. This is a must visit, only for the magnificence. Enjoy the splurge on the building. Take a guide, you would want to know some details

formatted_address: Rumeli Hisarı, Yahya Kemal Cd., 34470 Sarıyer/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Rumelihisarı

reviews.text: An Amazing place, a fortress built by the sea on the European side of Turkey. It has a great scenery and it was built in a very short time and few man. Big achievement to human kind. Must visit

A smashing trip with an important part of Ottoman history. Don’t miss this spectacular fortress and experience the force and security of the Ottoman Empire. A little disappointed that visitors are not allowed to climb to the top of the tower or view from bastions. Mind blowing 360 degree views of Istanbul and the Bosphorous - priceless. Good footwear is essential as can be a difficult climb for some, nevertheless well worth the visit.
An amazing strategic place back in the ottoman empire and a very important historical mark in Istanbul. Definitely significant place to visit 👍👍👍👍

Beautiful place! It gives you a sensation of history right from the gates. You must go and visit it even though it is a little bit far away from the city centre and the usual tourist route. I recommend you go there in a sunny morning so you can admire the full beauty of the Bosporus.

Amazing Place.
You can easily take a bus there from Taksim square.
If you love medieval fortress and architectures, this place is for you.
15 TL entry fee, or ticket price.
Note that they do not allow you walking on the walls of the fortress.

formatted_address: Cankurtaran, 34122 Fatih/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Istanbul Archaeological Museums

reviews.text: It has some interesting sarcophagus and ceramic pieces.  The rest of the museum was closed for reparations.  I saw many better museums in different cities in Turkey, including Ephesus and Sanliurfa. I thought this one in the capital city would have more pieces and more interesting ones, but I was mistaken. It’s not worth it, at least not until they open up the other parts that were closed when I visited (Aug 1, 2019)
The main museum is completely closed for renovation with only a tiny notice declaring so. Smaller sideshow museums were pretty decent to visit but not worth full ticket price.

In my visit, most rooms  were being refurbished. However, the available ones had interesting pieces, such as caskets beautifully sculpted which are (mostly)  part of the Roman heritage that settled in Turkey which makes this country very interesting, and full of History as a result of a clash of different cultures and this is self-evident in the pieces displayed in its different rooms.  The little garden in the café has a set of beautiful sculptures and statues that make it magical.  I hope  they finish the restoration soon. Highly recommended!!

Really cool exhibits, with some Sumerian pieces dating back to 2700-2400 BC. They have fragments of the world's first known peace treaty, the Treaty of Kadesh, between the ancient Egyptians and Hittites, which is really cool. One thing that really bummed me out though is that the "Istanbul through the ages" exhibit was closed off. That was one of the things I was looking forward to seeing the most ☹️
Very cool. However most of the main building is being renovated, so don't forget to go to the second building to see the second and third floor of the museum. It's a bit hard to find but worth it.

formatted_address: Emirgan, Sakıp Sabancı Cd. No:42, 34467 Sarıyer/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Sabancı University Sakıp Sabancı Museum

reviews.text: Best museum I went to in Istanbul. Very small but high-quality collection. The cafe is nice as well.

Nice park, Great terrace with a wonderful view of Bosphorus. Actually entrance is for free, if you want to visit park and restaurant only, but Tricky thing, they offer you to take a ticket at entrance, without saying that. And you don’t have to pay, if you are not going to visit museum. Was not going to visit exhibition so paid 35 lira is just for nothing.

Off the beaten track but so worth a visit. The exhibits were exquisite and the garden a gem! The view from the terrace was marvellous. We took a bus to get there from Kabatas and took the boat back. This was a treat too and inexpensive!

With a spectacular view of Bosphorus, one of the best museums. Museum itself, also the restaurants and other parts in it, must be visit and you should take your time here, especially in a mild weather
I visited the russian avantgarde exhibition, and it was incredibly informative. Great experience!

formatted_address: Eyüp Merkez, İdris Köşkü Cd., 34050 Eyüp/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Pierre Loti

reviews.text: The view is amazing. Family friendly place. It’s the best for some meditation or a special cup coffee with this unique view. The pictures had been taken around the sun shine in the morning. Highly recommended around the sunshine and sunset time. You will experience  the view in day and night time.

This place has a beautiful view of Istanbul.  You can have a little trouble getting up the hill.  There are three cafes on the hill.  They are all lovely there you can eat freeze on the verge of a very nice chat.  A very pleasant place to stay when you go.  Have a nice holiday.

The only reason I am giving this place 4/5 is just due to the stunning view over the Golden horn. Also it is a nice side effect that you need to take a lift to the hilltop. IT´s absolutely worth the trip and I would recommend taking the ferry.

Very pleasant location to take tea or coffee (Turkish variety, naturally) or a meal and enjoy the atmosphere and the outdoor view. Expansive. Be sure to see the large green ceramic heater inside and a display of coffee cups. Take the cable car up but, but!, walk down through the old Ottoman cemetery and marvels at the history and the art of inscribed tombstones of famous Ottomans. At the base of the hill, you'll reach the famous Enüp Sultan Mosque, which is really worth the visit.

A must visit place in Istanbul. The view of Golden Horn is where you will enjoy your best turkish coffee or fresh lemonade. The best time to go is in the summer or spring time. You can take a cup or a bus to reach there and go up hill by cable cars( you pay using the same city bus and metro card)

formatted_address: Hüseyinağa, Grand Pera, İstiklal Cd. no: 56/58, 34440 Beyoğlu/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Madame Tussauds Istanbul

reviews.text: Really interesting and fun place to be. You can see quite a number of stars, play video games and experience some of these key moments in history. There is a shop on your way out to pick up some souvenirs for family and friends. My favorite where the Bob Marley and Jackie Chan  sections.
The statues there are unbelievable. They look so real. So, don't miss the chance of visiting it if you are in Istanbul. You will like it
Characters do not even resemble in most of the cases... And there not many of them. And who cares about some Turkish bubble stars... Where are the historical important people?
It has a very few celebrities in that museum , so it is suggested that if possible one should visit in UK or Thailand. However, it’s good for the young age kids to visit.
A must visit in Istanbul, had many international figures and interactive acts. So much fun

formatted_address: 38, Mollafenari, Yeniçeriler Cd., 34120 Fatih/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Anadolu Nargile Çorlulu Ali Paşa Medresesi

reviews.text: The most original and preserved Narghilè place you can find in Istanbul. You will be there smoking and enjoying tea only with locals in a beautiful area. Do not miss at all!
Such a cool place to have Turkish coffee and Shisha! It’s not fancy or chic, but who needs that when the price and atmosphere are so great! Highly recommend coming here for both coffee and shisha.

A real “experience”. Turns out I can’t handle my hookah, passed out cold! Staff jumped to my aid, really well looked after by both them and the friendly patrons. Can’t recommend highly enough, but exercise caution, it’s stronger stuff than we’d had elsewhere! 

Thank you for looking after me and apologies for causing a scene!
Unusual hookah bar. Real Istanbul experience. Fantastic sheesha flavours, good beverages, outstanding service and magic local ambience. You have to give it a try!
Liked this place, will definetly recommend it. Felt like in the old times of istanbul, everything just raw, no fancy interior or exterior.

formatted_address: 19 Mayıs, Büyükdere Cd. No:22, 34360 Şişli/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Istanbul Cevahir

reviews.text: Huge and crowded shopping mall, one of the biggest in Europe. Many floors having a wide option of well known stores among many others. They offer a good amount of places where to eat also. And the design and decoration of the interior is always beautiful. Highly recommended.

One of the biggest shopping Mall's in Mecidikoy district of Istanbul on the European side of the City , very extensive array of high fashion and branded stores for clothes, furniture , soft furnishing, DIY store, home soft furnishing, Banks, Big Super Market, varied and huge Food Court, Entertainment, Movie houses, children's play areas and all kinds of Electronics, white goods and appliances well stocked and varied products stores.
Prices are medium to high. Very centrally located and extremely well connected by all kinds of mass transit systems.

All the shops one can desire..

There are a variety of shops in this mall from clothing to shoes.. Home decor, makeup and skincare, perfumes etc.

It's central location makes it easily accessible from which ever direction you are coming from either by bus, metrobus or by metro.

Will be shopping there again! :))

An elegant security passage featuring more clothing brands, exciting gaming gear. Very large supermarket. You do not have the right to sit in corridors. You must also pay for the safe deposit box and you must pay the box each time you open the box door.

Good shopping mall with a lot of brands with reasonable prices. 
 However the place is crowded and needs some more ventilation.
food is average.

formatted_address: Hoca Paşa Mahallesi Ankara Caddesi İstanbul TR, Hoca Paşa, Hocapaşa Hamamı Sk. 3/B, 34110 Fatih/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Hodjapasha

reviews.text: Must do for travellers to Istanbul who enjoy Rumi' s poetry. A truly spectacular show that transcends you to a spiritual plane. The artists and backdrop is so ethereal and amazing. Very well managed. Audience is required to observe silence during the show.  Photography is not allowed.

First and foremost, this theatre is historical and pretty much unchanged architecture since the olden times. While watching the show, I was trying to imagine how it must have been in the olden times when soundboxes & dazzling ligthing were not invented. Very artistic & romantic place. I enjoyed the show thoroughly and was a spectacle to the eyes and ears. Professionals performed their best with great synchronization & rhythm. A must visit to anyone who hasn't seen it.

BEST SUFI DANCING DERVISH IN TOWN! I booked via Expedia a day before because there is an education piece, free drink and every seat is a good seat in the house. From the reviews this seems the only legit place you can book a seat, everyone is seated, and a very professional ceremony. DO NOT attend if you have no interest in mystics or spirituality - most kids and adults fell asleep. Also YOU DO NOT HAVE TO COVER UP - I wore jeans in 30 degree temp and the guy who seated us was in shorts!

The show of Rythm of the Dance is moderately good. The dances and choreography are quite basic and simple and you can see the overly rehearsed faces of the dancers that have been doing the same routine three times a week for years, specially in the women dancers.
The theater is good to be in and there are a couple of dances worth watching. I overall would recommend going here to get an overview of traditional dancing if you just have a few days in town.

I'll split my review into three parts, one for the location, one for the Sufi/Dervish show and one for the Turkish dance show.

Alright, so the location is great, the hammam is restored well and acts a good setting. The way the information about dancing is displayed within the centre is also good in my opinion. The layout for the stage also makes you feel quite close to the action.

Moving on to the Sufi/Dervish show, the show was terrible. Its boring and a waste of time and it was most likely one of the worst shows I have ever watched. I fell asleep during the show multiple times and I was sitting in the front row. My disappointment comes from the fact that I've seen multiple Sufi shows in Egypt and Turkey. There are better shows in Istanbul, don't go to the Sufi show here, it isn't worth your time or money. Thankfully, this show is held as a separate event from the other dance show held here. 

Now, to the last part. The Turkish dance show is simply great, its energetic, it fun and simply worth going to. Its great value for money, and a decent way to either or end or start the night.

formatted_address: Anadolu Kavağı, 34825 Beykoz/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Anadolu Kavağı

formatted_address: Osmanağa, Söğütlü Çeşme Cd No:61, 34714 Kadıköy/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Kadıköy Bull Statue

reviews.text: So many previous location finally ended up where it is most known... Kadikoy's main meeting point. Definitely a Must see

This old fashioned market type looks so good. Especially it’s opened and the weather was very good. The outlet has a very cheap clothing including sunglasses, tshirts, caps and much more! There are some restaurants too over there. And it was not that crowded when I visited it. But i belive it gets crowded sometimes especially in holy days.

Statue of historic cow! Comed from streets of Paris to Istanbul! 
The Iron Cow has travelled around  the Europe in the World War, Has finally arrived here.

One of Best places to be while in İstanbul. Many attractions around. Catch ferry to small islands. Night life is very good. Fish market is there and next to it there are seafood restaurants. Many stores that sell antique jewelry. Very reasonable prices. At the end of the bahariye street there is a bar which I fell in love with. Looks like old British pub serving all kinds of beers from all over the world.
I love this place but i am always wondering why all the tourists take pictures with the statue 😅😅😅

formatted_address: Asmalı Mescit, Meşrutiyet Cd. No:99, 34430 Beyoğlu/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Istanbul Museum of Modern Art

reviews.text:
Great exhibitions that are arranged very neatly. My favourite was the photography exhibition going on right now. The environment was very pleasing too. 

However, the staff there weren't very nice. Especially the counter staff who ignored us while we were intending to purchase tickets. Other than that, demanded us to pay very rudely, which was really uncalled for. Truly apalled.

Fantastic collections and very well arranged. I recommend using audio guides, despite of them being old and not very user friendly, as the audio-comments were very accurate and interesting. A must is you are in Istanbul.. and perfect for a rainy afternoon plan.

Nicely and neatly presented collection of modern art coming out of Turkey. A decent change in the middle of all the ancient sites around the city.

The cafe there serves some of the best food in Istanbul for a decent price, eat there, thank me later.
Uniqur museum in Istanbul. The view was amazing before port construction. It has lost some of its appeal because of the construction project.
A small museum for people who do not like to spend hours at the museum. The cashiers were very welcoming. It's great to start the visit of a museum with such kind and smiling people

formatted_address: Sultan Ahmet, Ayasofya Meydanı, 34122 Fatih/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Hagia Sophia Museum

reviews.text: In my opinion, this is the most impressive building in the world. Its age and size are spectacular. If you have no interest in churches or mosques, you still ought to come here. To stand where the emperors of Rome once stood is a truly humbling experience. Come at 9-10am if you can; it gets much busier shortly after that.

The famous basilica-come-mosque-come-museum. Ancient as the city itself, it is the main attraction here. 
There were some restorations around the main hall so we could not see 100% of the museum. However, the building is wonderful and you can smell the history there.
Plan 2 hours for the museum.

Any tourist will appreciate the beauty and the history of this place. A true must have. This church is so dramatic in its size that even during the busiest day you'll not feel cramped inside.  Imagine a 1000 years ago, what it was like to build such a masterpiece in a city with merely 200,000 people.

An orthodox will have a nostalgic pain deep in their heart of the times passed standing in this holy place.

One of my favourite places in the world. There is so much history and energy in the air. This was my 3rd time visiting this place, unfortunately there was some renovations going on , so the left side of the interior was covered in scaffolding. If you only have a limited time in Istanbul then this place is No.1 on the list of sites to see. Rich in history and meaning, this site will not fail to amaze you.

This is such a beautiful place, they are restoring it so one side of the big mosque is closed off with a scaffolding. I would definitely recommend anybody wish coming to Istanbul the police check this place out. There are wonderful art Works wonderful history and a lot of great things to see in this mosque. There are tour guides to walk around the mosque and you can get a earpiece to tell you every place in the mosque it is definitely worth the money if you would like to get it to a guy to tour you around the mosque. Please be careful when going to the Blue Mosque as it will be under construction for the rest of 2019.

formatted_address: Göztepe Mah. Ömerpaşa Cad. Doktor Zeki Eren Sok. No:17, Göztepe, 34730 Kadıköy/İstanbul, Turkey
name: İstanbul Oyuncak Müzesi

reviews.text: The people who work there are the kindest. One of the best toy collections I've seen and they are very well organized, and the attention to detail is more than amazing. The museum is in an old cute home giving you a feeling of going back it time. A very great experience for kids and adults. Finally the shop there has a lot of handmade products with very unique and reasonably to cheap prices. The seller of the shop is a very nice and enthusiastic girl and is the nicest person I've met. If I could I would give it more than 5 stars.

Great little museum on the Asian side of Istanbul. Very original, beautiful house converted to a boutique toy museum. There is something for children and adults alike. Don't miss the outdoors garden Cafe and try their trademark San Sebastián cheese cake together with a freshly brewed Coffee. A hidden gem waiting to be discovered 👍

There are many toys from early 1900s from all around the world. The most common manufacturer countries were Germany (which is the best with a huge difference) and the USA.

You need at least 1.5 hours to check all the rooms in detail.
Very warm and good atmosphere for kids. You can also remember your childhood :) Also nice cafeteria and smiling and helpful  staff

Like the Mint Museum in Singapore, the Toy Museum in Istanbul has an excellent college, but mostly from Germany, USA, Japan and England. For young kids willing to learn more about Toys, this is a must visit. 30 mins max

formatted_address: Küçük Ayasofya, Küçük Ayasofya Cami Sk. No:20, 34122 Fatih/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Little Hagia Sophia

reviews.text: A bright gem in Istanbul. Formerly a church built in the time of the Byzantine emperor Justinian (6th century CE), it became a mosque in the Ottoman period and functions as such today. It is a serene and refreshing place in the midst of the city, so leave time to relax and reflect. Not as busy as other places. This is not a place you will regret seeing!
A quaint and peaceful mosque that's built like a mini version of the actual Hagia Sophia. Located in the main area of Sultanahmet and at a walking distance from the Blue Mosque.

Interesting from the outside. We waited few hours drinking coffee in the garden for the mosque to opens, but no one came. According to the worshipers it happens way too often on Sundays. We could not wait more, so.... Till the next time

The 1st time we got there a few days ago, mosque was closed for cleaning and we prayed outside. We went there again 2 days later and experenced a majestically beautiful mosque. A miniture of the larger Hagia Sophia.
An old church converted to a mosque, short walk downhill from Sultanahmet Square, it is worth a visit.

formatted_address: Yavuz Sultan Selim, Dr. Sadık Ahmet Cd. No:44, 34083 Fatih/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Ecumenical Orthodox Patriarchate

reviews.text: It is a place worth visiting,whether you are orthodox christian or not. The history of this place,of people who have taken care of it,the details,and relics that are here are just stunning. You won't be sorry for visiting it.

Great place to see a different side of Istanbul and understand how multiple religions are welcomed in the country. Free to enter. The church interior is small but filled with some wonderful wall ornaments and pictures. You will only spend about 15 minutes in this place. Don't go out of your way just to see this, only go if you're in the area already (FYI - the colourful houses of balat are nonexistent and mostly dull).

A lovely oasis of calm in the middle of this chaotic city. If you are lucky you will get to meet or see the Patriarch Bartolomew. Forget the crowds at the Vatican, here you may have the whole complex to yourself.  The interior is awe inspiring from the icons to the incense and candles. Do not miss out on walking around the local neighborhood. There are jewels from all the Jewish, Christian and Islamic faiths found around every corner.

Worth a stop when you are in the area. We went in during a christening and it was interesting to witness the ceremony. Make sure to explore the area, very fun place and not as touristy as Sultanhemet or Taksim.
Beautiful church. Very traditional, very calming. For me it was good to learn about the differences been this and other branches of Christianity.

formatted_address: Şahkulu Mh., Galip Dede Cd. No:15, 34420 Beyoğlu/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Galata Mevlevihanesi Müzesi

reviews.text:
The Whirling Dervishes show was excellent  and felt authentic. The venue is also very beautiful. I would highly recommend this. The only downside is that the ticket price is now 100TL. 

I removed one star, because they didn’t have enough chairs so we (and many others) had to stand for the entire one hour show. So get there at least 45 minutes before if you want a chair. Also they don’t provide any information in English about the meaning of show.

Just go through its gates on to the beautiful quite garden that is an excellent spot to take a breath from the crowded istiklal road. It's a great spot to buy the Museum Pass as it's less crowded than other spots like Hagya Sofia or Topkapi. 
The museum is well kept and not too long to go through but it gives a thorough look into the Dervish tradition, history and religion. Don't miss the hall near the museum where certain days of the week you can witness a dervish ceremony and dance.

Great for those who are interested in Mevlevi and their life. Nice and well kept museum. Today we witnessed Whirling Dervishes show at 1700 hours. That was amazing. For getting these tickets please come Saturday or Sunday morning at 1000 hours.

Galata mevlevihanesi is a very interesting stop. If you wonder who is Mevlana and what did he do, you can come and visit here. It's not so big but it's a nice place to taste every bit of mevlevi culture. Also you can find Ottoman Calligraphy examples and a few old instruments.

I went to the Dervish ceremony. I would only recommend it if you are really, really interested (and happy to donate your money for the cause). The price it is 100 Turkish Lira. 
The refused to make reservation, when I arrived 15 min before, told me it was full already, they asked me to wait just in case of a free spot, after a few minutes they sold me a ticket (also to the other 10 people behind me, so, yes, it was space, they just wanted us to wait in the rain).

formatted_address: Asmalı Mescit, Meşrutiyet Cd. No:65, 34430 Beyoğlu/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Pera Müzesi

reviews.text: It took about an hour to go through all 4 floors of art. The building is well kept and clean, the staff are nice and the art is beautiful. I would for sure recommend this especially if you're in the area!
Wonderful collection with good interpretive signage. Convenient location near Istiklal Street.

Pera Museum is one of the well established Museum in Istanbul. The architecture is amazing and the collection is marvellous. Even if you do not like Turkish art you can go and see "The Tortoise Trainer" which is a milestone for Turkish painting. After seeing collection you can go to good museum cafe...
interesting art in a great building. The ambient pieces playing on the 4th floor was fantastic.

This museum offers a wide variety of pieces on display from fine to contemporary arts.  Well worth 2 hours of your day to explore the four different levels.  They also have a nice display showing ancient measurement tools from the Anatolia region.

formatted_address: Binbirdirek, Piyer Loti Cd. No:25, 34122 Fatih/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Theodosius Cistern

reviews.text: This place is,in my opinion,great visiting opportunity. It has a lot of history,it is beautifully taken care of,and the entry is free of charge. They also added sound effects of water dripping,which really makes the whole experience much better,and there are also some artworks,sculptures to be exact,that are very interesting.
Great, beautiful and very well renovated. An excellent work. More quiet and calm than Basilical Cistern. And free entrance! Well done Istanbul council!

A new excavation and museum near the more well known Cistern museum. This one is a multistory glass building on a Sultanahmet triangular intersection reaching down below ground level. This has free entry, no lines, and a cool empty feel when I was there. I'm glad I found this before the bulk of visitors do.
Superb mixture of engineering, art and history. A must see. And look in at Ruby Ceramics across the road at the same time. You won't regret it!
A must visit in Istanbul.  Much better than basilica cistern. Recently reconstructed, filled with water,  modern artwork inside. It is free of charge and easily accessible by walking.

formatted_address: Caferağa, Yasa Cd. No:46, 34714 Kadıköy/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Misir Carsisi

reviews.text:
Came here just to browse and overheard a lady purchasing Salep powder (a typical Turkish winter beverage - orchid powder) and got some myself. The man at the counter didn’t speak much English but he went above and beyond by showing me how to properly prepare the drink with the help of Translator and a teaspoon.
Turkish hospitality ⭐️
Great market area
Much smaller than the markets over in the touristic areas of the Asian side, but somehow this one is more charming.
average. so crowded with people but you can get things with good deals.

Kadıköy çarşısı, artık birçok semtte kalmayan İstanbul'un tarihi semt çarşılarından sonuncusu. Güler yüzlü ve kibar esnafları, kaliteli gıda çeşitleri ve şarküteri ürünleriyle her zaman tercih edilen bir çarşı.

formatted_address: Tomtom, İstiklal Cd. No:171, 34433 Beyoğlu/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Sent Antuan Kilisesi

reviews.text: I love to go here and pray. It makes me feel lighter every time
Good and calm place. No one is allowed to go in front of church side for praying even its mentioned as front side is only for praying

This church is located at the main Taksim Square a very famous shopping area and lively place for eating, lots of good restaurants and tourist around all the time.   
One of the oldest church in Istanbul, Many tourist were visiting it from inside. Still the Christmas tree and manager  was there making it more beautiful. I visited it in the evening, as I happen to pass by from here and saw this beautiful piece of Italian architecture. It's very old and beautiful church. Loved it !!!

So if you're a Muslim like me, yet interested in the religious diversity of Istanbul - then this is the place. Go out - learn more about other religion. For sure that will help you to be an even better Muslim!
It's right in the heart of the bustling shopping area of Taksim Square. You can just drop in and light a candle or two and then resume your shopping.

formatted_address: Merkezefendi, 34015 Zeytinburnu/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Topkapı Panorama 1453

reviews.text: Great museum
Osmanlı tarihinde Fatih Sultan Mehmet Han'ın İstanbul'u fethettiği savaşı görseli ve arka fon müzikleri ile çok güzel canlandıran bir yer mutlaka herkesin bir gün gitmesi gerek
Muhtesem sanli tarihimi ve gecmisimi yasadim boyle bir sanli tarihi olan bir milletin ferdi olarak atalarimla gecmisimle gurur duydum
Muhteşem bir yer. Kesinlikle ziyaret edilmeli.
İstanbul'un fethini idrak etmek için güzel bir müze.

formatted_address: Levent, Büyükdere Cd. No:185, 34394 Şişli/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Kanyon

reviews.text: It's a unique mall with great architecture and outdoor feels. Great place to not just shop but also relax. You can simply purchase a freshly-squeezed juice and walk around the sunlight like you're in a public park. And you do all this in a SHOPPING MALL. There are all types of stores available here, ranging from slightly lower to extreme high class. Very accessible via bus, metro and marmaray.

reviews.author_name: Kam's Training Eğitim ve Iş Danışmanlığı
reviews.text: Shoppoing there reflects a contemporary way of living in Istanbul. Make no mistake you will see more white collar and upper town shoppers. The number of cafes and restaurants adds a lovely ambiance to the shopping experience. The mall is one of the very few Malls that plays contemporary live music specially during lunch breaks and weekends.

It's nice open mall contains several brands, coffee shops nice to take break and have a coffee or tea during the shopping. There is no mosque in the mall. The parking for first 3 hours free then you have to pay through a machine. The most important thing it's not crowded.

One of my favorite hangout places in Istanbul. This open air mall offers a taste of luxury and refinement that is always wonderful to experience. From the European style cafes and restaurants to the mini water fountains that add a sweet ambience which makes this mall a must see.

Very open mall, primarily outdoors, designed to look, as the name suggests, like a canyon. Good selection of stores and restaurants in addition to a movie theater. Only problem is that in the winter the mall functions like an actual canyon, and is an absolutely frigid wind tunnel.

formatted_address: Mimar Sinan, 34664 Üsküdar/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Mihrimah Sultan Mosque

reviews.text: Amazing mosque withe old heritage. It's built by Mimar sinan the most popular arctic in ottoman empire. The restrictions done recently so it becomes more beautiful. It's a central mosque in Üsküdar so it's all the time full of people. The imam has a significant voice so you should visit in time of praying. It's so close to the sea so it's have a good view in the balcony.
Majestic design, architected by the infamous Sinan.  Right near the Bosphorous where the ferry port is.  Gorgeous views

Beautiful mosque though the bus station and constant politicking that goes on in front of it detracts from the beauty of the place. This is another mosque built by the great court architect Sinan in 1548 in the honour of Mihrimah, favorite daughter of Sultan Süleyman the magnificent. There is another mosque built by Mimar Sinan in Edirnekapı by the same name aslo built for the same Mihrimah.

It's a very historic Mosque 🕌
You may find almost all the mosques in İstanbul with the same architecture and pattern, however, this Mosque is unique as the most famous architect Mimar Sinan built it himself.
Üsküdar Ferry Station is just nearby and if you take a walk of 20 minutes, you can reach Salacak Sahil which is a beautiful place with amazing views of Maiden Tower.

One of the uniq historical mosques made by Mimar Sinan. It's in Uskudar and seaside. And also one of the rare culture of Ottoman Adhans, which is been call Duplicate Adhan, is still alive in 2 locations. Mihrimah is one of them.  They are reciting adhan by featuring. Mihrimah Sultan Mosque and the other mosque infront of it Valide Mosque . Worth to hear it once in life with the beautiful Istanbul cats& seagulls and Bosphorus view...

formatted_address: Binbirdirek, Sultan Ahmet Parkı No:2, 34122 Fatih/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Sultanahmet Square

reviews.text:
I love the atmosphere day and night. Families gathered together making picnic, playing,  laughing,  buses going everywhere and trams as well. You have cash points and the tourist police 24/7. You can snack on some sweetcorn (5TL) or chestnuts (10TL to 30 TL) which are delicious.  As you sit down to watch your environment,  people selling water(1TL), tea or coffee will offer everyone for 3TL. One evening  as I was sitting on a bench drinking tea, I was approached by a 25 year old man, he started to talk very respectfully so I didn't mind a conversation until he started to flirt. Perfect if that is what you are looking for. 
I have seen some Turkish guys pretending to be Spanish which I am, to a Korean tourist trying to take him for drinks.  It was a bit strange and I would be careful.  If you have any problems,  talk to the police, present all over the square.
Amazing restaurants offering homemade Turkish food for around 32TL (food, drink and bread). The restaurant is called Can. Other similar ones along the tram line.

Nice historical place. But beware people talking to you. They looked so nice and friendly but they always want to get something from you or make you pay something. It's a shame really. Because you would not dare to talk to anyone. And some people may genuinely nice

Great place to relax during sightseeing. always vendors selling simit and corn. Cross the street to the west and buy some ice cream, then cross back and enjoy it on a bench while watching the people from all over the world. There are great views here, between ayasofia mosque and the blue mosque.
The atmosphere was like nothing else. The place is loaded with historical buildings and can easily take all day walking, exploring and sightseeing.
The place is full of history and really well organized. You can spend two or three days visiting it's surroundings alone.

formatted_address: Eminönü, Hobyar, 34112 Fatih/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Eminonu Pier

reviews.text: Good port for taking a ferry, it's convenient and pretty cheap. Why to pay a tourist boat when you can take a public transport boat for a few lira... We took a boat to prince island from there, it was also much cheaper than taking all these special boat (but it took over 1h to go there with a handful of stop). If you want to go to prince island, take the earliest boat and don't come back too late too.
We wanted Bosporus cruise. It was one among the wish list. To explore and see the water that divides Asia from Europe. To see the rich houses on the banks and to enjoy the much heard fish sandwiches.
Great view.. main attraction.. transportation by tram or ferry from there to many places in Istanbul.. you can enjoy sitting there at night drinking a cup of tea or coffee
Best place in istanbul to spend the afternoon and the sunset time temp. Is very nice (at summer )

I think everyone will visit Istanbul should come to this port because it has a lot of services in addition to a nice view of the bosphore. You can use this port to take the bosphore tour which it takes either 4h or 1h depending on your choice and you can ride to the other side of Istanbul using this port too.

formatted_address: Sinanpaşa, Beşiktaş Cd. 6/1, 34353 Beşiktaş/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Maritime Museum

reviews.text: Just beautiful maritime museum, lots of ship samples from 1500s. You will love it. Entry fee 10 lira. Has elevators to go to other floors if you don’t want to take the stairs or ramp based walks. Bathrooms on first floor. Great cafe at the entrance / exit area. It has inside and outside seating, with lots of seats. Nice clean, nice smiley servers. Gift shop is currently closed. You will enjoy the place, need an hour to walk around.

The best organized museum in Istanbul, airconditioned, well planed, new, well displayed nice collection and with lots of information. Nice cafe with terrace and jazz.. beer.. Shop was closed when we visited. Very small and poor choice.
A very interesting museum. An important landmark! Full of history, you can see unique pieces from theTurkish Navy s old times. It is a must place to be seen in Istanbul.
Amazing museum. A must-visit spot in Istanbul. A collection of unique imperial boats and gondolas. The diving section also interesting and actually jaw breaking!

The entrance ticket costs 50 tl you need 3 hours to go through everything and see everything I recommend you to try the sweets in their cafe the mini egyptian bazar prices are touristy and the founder of the museum is their everyday

formatted_address: Kemer, İstanbul Üniversitesi Orman Fakültesi, 34450 Bahçeköy / Sarıyer/Sarıyer/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Atatürk Arboretum

reviews.text: Very nice Park in the Forest. Very clean. No food allowed in there. Great place to relax and rake some nice pictures. Too big to discover in one day. Restaurants are close to the park 45 min to walk

Good place to be with family or alone great forest i just be happy..  so so happy 😁 
Nice people in the gate and there is a nice girls in the gate work in this forest and help me so much .. i want to say thank u all so much with love ♥️

Beautiful aspects of the quiet place to be calm but peaceful.

fungus

Nice to have benches for seating next to the pond

It's nice to have a bus.

Extremely expensive

food and water are not taken.

Looks like we're attending the interpersonal meeting.

Car park fits in the middle of the road, where all the cars that fits 15 vehicles

Lastly, it is worth to go to my followers.If you have plenty of time and time, or if you are in high school, it is not worth going.
Beautiful nature and scenery. A little far from old city but was worth the trip. It is easy to get there by bus.

Lovely relaxing park. You can take beautiful pics there.
Not so far from taksim, you can take the bus 42T directly to the square.

formatted_address: Hocapaşa Mahallesi Ankara Cadddesi,Halil Lütfü 4. İş Merkezi K: 1 No:113,Hoca Paşa,, Hoca Paşa, 34110 Fatih/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Marmaray Sirkeci İstasyonu

reviews.text: Never ever have I ever received such bad treatment from a service. The staff working on the bulgaria to turkey train are corrupt forcing me to pay them money or they’d throw me off the train regardless of me showing the ticket and receipt of my purchase 20 minutes earlier.

Its the Marmaray train station near to Eminonu square and closed to Serkeci tramway station too only 1 min walking, you can use it too to go to Asian part of turkey if you want to reach faster than ferry

Ended up here after traveling for a week using Interrail and what an experience, after typical European stations for most of the way, we definitely knew we had arrived somewhere very special,. Glad to see it doesn't appear to have changed much.
Great train!  Runs right under the Bosporus and is earthquake resistant!
very comfortable way to reach Asian side of Istanbul.

formatted_address: Çubuklu Mah, Hidiv Kasrı Cd. No. 1/1, 34805 Beykoz/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Hidiv Kasri

reviews.text:
‪A restaurant, woods and even artificial waterfall. You never felt that you are being in rush Istanbul with the traffic etc. while you are visiting this place. It makes you calm, relaxed, refreshed and happy when you leave.‬

‪It has moderate restaurant(which is not luxury in terms of price) with the good offers of dishes. Open buffet breakfast available on the weekends. Restaurant has indoor and outdoor dining tables. For those who want to have a picnic with the loved ones. There are some picnic tables available near by the parking lot. Sad but, you are unable to visit the tower of the palace.‬

‪It was originally a privately owned house which belongs one of the Ottoman governor and sold to the Istanbul municipality. Renovated and available to the public visitors. ‬

A place that you should visit with the family, you can enjoy the whole day there, with a very nice garden and fresh air away from the city and the noise. Nice historical buildings around, you wont be able to stop yourself from going inisde the building and trying to explore each corner of it imagining people who lived there hundreds of years ago. Absolutely recommended

The palace was magnificent view green land water fall
It need transportation facility to become more visited

A must visit site
Amazing resturant with subsidies prices buvthe baladeyesi open buffet
Good place, its just a resturant nothing more.

formatted_address: Sanayi, 1678. Sk. No:19, 34538 Esenyurt/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Pelit Çikolata Müzesi

reviews.text: Very nice museum. Sculptures are made of chocolate. They have sculptures of famous people and buildings.They give chocolate as you go and it tasted very delicious. They also sell chocolate.

place in the well known chocolate factory..
Well organised museum.
Has two parts: first one with different models for cultural, famous and well known places and persons ... second one is for cartoon's models...All made from chocolate..
You can also test the chocolate fall directly..
At the end you can buy something as souvenirs...
Recommended and enjoyable place
Nice place with friendly people. Many choices. Good service. The taste is irresistible.
Excellent place. It is underrated. We were a family and like it a lot. It is bigger than what you think. It is also informative. Highly recommended when you visit istanbul.

The museum entrance ticket is 50TL, nice spectacular and figures made of chocolate, they gave us a chocolate bare at the entrance with some chocolate to taste at their shop. Overall good experience, yet their products prices are similar or slightly higher compared to the same chocolate quality in other stores at Istanbul.

formatted_address: Rasimpaşa, 34716 Kadıköy/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Haydarpasa Train Station

reviews.text:
Historical Station
In 2018, remains of a Byzantine coastal town have been found during the restoration works of the Haydarapaşa railway station. Furthermore, excavations unearthed a Byzantine-era fountain, a big fortification wall and a ceramic brick kiln 
Also, dozens of graves have been unearthed during excavations. In October 2018, archaeologists found an intact skeleton, which has a scented necklace on it. In addition, coins and jewellery were found in the field. Some coins were so clean that their period can easily be seen. The coins date back to between 610-641 and 527-565 A.D.
I love traveling by trains, and the trains between Istanbul and Ankara were really good. 3 times faster than the ones we have in California!

Elegant historical train station that is serving up to this time. Now it has the terminal for YHT ( high speed train) which connects Istanbul to Ankara in less than 4 hours. Turkey is really getting to the highest levels in technology.

Haydarpasa Train Station in considered one of ancient treasure of Turkey. Most amazingly is that the station is located right at the very tip of Asia continent along a beautiful coastline just over a mile away from Europe :-) . This station is one among the most photography in  Istanbul.
Beautiful and grand old railway station, located right by the water, check out the skyline of the European side from here (especially around sunset, it's magical!) and watch the ferries go by

formatted_address: Yeşilpınar, Şht. Metin Kaya Sk. No:11, 34065 Eyüp/İstanbul, Turkey
name: İsfanbul Eğlence ve Yaşam Merkezi

reviews.text: This mall is extraordinary, the parking is enormous, the internal shopping mall is great and has all of major brands. The food court is vast with lots of seating areas and lots of restaurants. The external market is also very nice, an internal tramway can commute the visitors around the block. Now, to the main attraction: The theme park. It is incredibly nice, don't miss the "breathtaking tail" and all the other stuff, it accommodates for children starting 3 years till fully grown up adults. All in all great experience.

Unique place for extreme fun and adrenaline enhancement! The adult ticket is about 239 Turkish lira, including all the fun in the park for the whole day, no matter how many times you get on one of them! Children can also have fun with 3 or 4D screenings, for the smallest have an animators. Personally, I enjoyed the trains and especially the 360 ​​degree view where you dived with the head down from 18 meters tall. And to what they are firing at 110km per hour and you are spinning! The feeling is unique! The Atraction is located in the largest open-air mall.
Better than expected. Needed more rides. But overall it is an enjoyable 1 day trip. It is attached to an amazing mall that makes the experience even a better one. Loved it and would do it again.

Price was 260 TL per adult and just a bid less for a child. It wasn't that crowded but not not too many rides. A family of 5 to 7 will pay between 1500 TL to 2000 TL, but can kill 4 to 5 hours max. I gave it 3 stars because there were not many things for children less that 8 years and their parents to do. However, teenagers will find it entertaining for sure. I would have given it 4 stars if prices were more reasonable considering its half an hour to 40 min away from the city. The jungle was bunch of trapped animals but many snakes.

I read the reviews and got discouraged but then the taxi driver told us it was nice so we gave it a go. It’s very nice and my 2 year old son had fun in the kids games, unlike the reviews that said only teenagers would have fun.
Maybe these kids games are new so go if you come to Istanbul!!

name: Arasta Bazaar

reviews.text: Un pequeño bazar acogedor

name: Nuruosmaniye Mosque

reviews.text:
Very calm and peaceful. 
Pro tip: go inside the mosque to see amazing marbel carvings.
Second pro tip: dress up nicely and go behind the mosque for killer pics.

A beautiful 18th century European baroque style mosque, with many stain glass windows.
Quiet and serene, a peaceful break from the hustle and bustle of the grand bazaar right next door.
Very beautiful and old mosque ; you should enter inside to see amazing artwork
Very  nice. Calm and soothing atmosphere. Masjid (Mosque) is magnificent.
An architectural gem. Peaceful, welcoming and the Imam's recitation is beautiful!

formatted_address: Rumeli Hisarı, Balta Limanı Hisar Cd. No:5, 34470 Sarıyer/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Borusan Contemporary

reviews.text: Modern art collection in an operating office building. The exhibitions are only open on the weekends. Two floors are dedicated to exhibit while the rest of the collection is spread throughout the offices. The offices themselves are designed and furnished in a nice mid-century modern style . Especially the CEO top floor office is amazing, if alone for the hifi system. Great Bosporus views from every floor.

Very interesting institution in a fabulous position on the Bosphoros. It is essentially an office building of the Borusan Holding company, and doubles as a contemporary art museum on weekends when the offices are open to the public to view the art. There are also some non-office spaces as well. The art is nicely curated and displayed, and the place definitely deserves a visit. What makes the visit even more attractive is the little Cafe annexed to the museum, with stunning views of the Bosphoros and the impressive bridge.
A good viewing platform, which is only available on weekends. The ascent upwards costs 10 lire, but stunning views open from the roof.

The location and the building are spectacular, really not sure about the exhibition though. Interesting but it would not be worth the trip if it wouldn’t be for the location. Entrance fee is 10TL...more than fair. 

The restaurant is underwhelming.
What an amazing and unique exhibition hall. ✨💖

reviews.text: Great place, felt reconnected to my Jewish roots
because its Moslem please
you need to go with an IDF escort. they go about 5 to 8 times every year
Its a very interesting place , but half of the makam there is the church side and half is masjid side ....
He is a bible hero

formatted_address: Göksu, Küçüksu Cd., 34815 Beykoz/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Küçüksu Palace

reviews.text: one of the staples of baroc-rococo architecture in istanbul. you can see the visiting hours and fees on one of my photos. yes we missed the hour and couldn’t get in :)
Magical and historical place. The view iş almost perfect.
One of the top spots I have ever been. Top European palace - absolute must go.
Had a short stay at Kucuksu Place during Bus and Boat tour of Istanbul. Beautiful garden next to palace. There is restoration work in progress at one side of the palace.
Beautiful museum, they are providing free audio guides in english, turkish and arabic. Perfect for the short visit (max an hour).

formatted_address: Süleymaniye Mah., 34116 Fatih/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Mausoleum of Sultan Suleyman the Magnificent

reviews.text: MAKE TURKEY OTTOMAN AGAIN! MAKE TURKEY POWERFUL AGAIN!Tomb of Suleiman the Magnificent; Istanbul Walled City Suleymaniye The Suleymaniye Complex was built on the 377th island, parcel 5 in the grave of the complex. Suleiman the Magnificent, the tenth Ottoman sultan. He was the son of Yavuz Sultan Selim who was born in Hafsa Sultan on 27 April 1495 in Trabzon. He was raised from a young age with good manners and collections. When he was the governor of Manisa, his father Yavuz Sultan Selim died on September 22, 1520, 30 September 1520 was the throne. He personally participated in thirteen expeditions during his sultanate and these expeditions were successful.

This is the resting place of Sultan Suleiman I, commonly known as Suleiman the Magnificent in the West and Kanunî Sultan Süleyman (Ottoman Turkish: قانونى سلطان سليمان‎; "The Lawgiver Suleiman") in his realm, was the tenth and longest-reigning Sultan of the Ottoman Empire from 1520 until his death in 1566. Under his administration, the Ottoman state ruled over at least 25 million people.
It is located within the Sultan Suleiman Mosque's complex. Around its Tomb there is also a tomb of his wife and many other graves of his relatives and Pashas.

The resting place of Sultan Suleyman and some of his wives, sons and daughters. It is located in front of the mosque complex, within a cemetery, all sharing the same compound.  What a sultan, king of law, and lover of Justice!!! That is what occurred to me right after entering this mausoleum. It is worth visiting

My love for Istanbul and Turkey starts with Sultan Suliman and Huram Sultan. So that is why I visited Istanbul
Lovely place and I enjoyed a lot as my wish come true.

Beautiful garden 

Nice one 

is the practice of growing and cultivating plants as part of horticulture. In gardens, ornamental plants are often grown for their flowers

formatted_address: Cankurtaran, Taya Hatun Sk 8A, 34122 Fatih/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Istanbul Museum of the History of Science and Technology in Islam

reviews.text: I did enjoy many of the items & mechanisms on display, but I must give it only one star seeing as my brother who  has a condition that forces him to have to visit the restroom at any given time was unable to enjoy a thing. The nearest bathroom is located outside the museum and since the ticket is for a single entrance, he needed to leave and couldnt re-enter. Word of warning to anyone who wants to visit this museum.

This museum offers an interesting view on the role of islam in science. This is an ofter forgotten side of history.
Nevertheless, some parts are really unclear. Most pieces are just reproductions. There are a huge lot of them, but sometimes no explanation about how it works (or a few ones, very technical).
The museum was great, incredibly informative. The interactive part of the exhibit was not functioning, this made the visit a little boring for little kids.
What a waist of time... Boring exhibition, not a single original peace in it... All cheep machined copies. Do not waist your time. Generally like Istanbul museums, but definitely not this one.

To be honest, I would not really call it a museum. All the exhibits are copies, and yet it's equally not a typical science museum where you get to try out the items or carry out mini experiments. Additionally, even though it's interesting to learn about science in the Muslim countries, the tone of the narration was very anti-West and aggressive. It's as if they use a certain level of propaganda there. I prefer to separate museums from national agendas :)

formatted_address: Caferiye Sokak, Cankurtaran, Soğukkuyu Çk. No:5, 34122 Fatih/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Cafer Ağa Medresesi

reviews.text: Quaint courtyard in tourist area. It also has many local artists and opportunities to take part in a course. Food is simple menu but good.
the area around suleymania cami is great

Ambiance with historic biilding, traditional handcrat ateliers... enjoy your time hete by sipping your wonderful turkish tra or coffee. This place just next to Sultanahmet Square where full of historic buildings and monuments sush as hagia sophia, the blue mosque, mosaic museup, topkapi palace, ibrahimpasa palace, french prison
...
If you want a real breakfast or brunch it’s the place to be
A hidden gem in the busy and touristic neighborhood of Aya Sofia. We had an amazing coffee here, far away from the busy crowds. It's kind of tricky to locate but it deserves the fuss.

formatted_address: Kalenderhane Mah., Haşim İşcan Gç., 34134 Fatih/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Valens Aqueduct

reviews.text: Difficult to get a good photo but still worth the walk to see it. If you are in Istanbul during winter the you should  be able to get a better view and photo of it as most of the trees will lose theirs leafs. There is a small local walking street to the north, well overdue of some rain to wash away the urine smell. Best to walk south towards the university as there are plenty of nice restaurants there.
Area is well preserved and easy to reach. Gives you a general idea of acquaducts. I am not sure it is possible to observe it closely. There is a well maintained park near acquaducts.
Simply historical, there's not much you can do around them ... but definitely take a picture of them for the gallery... I would recommend visiting the fatih mosque and then walking towards them

Impressive historical Roman-era Aqueduct running through the heart of old Istanbul. While ~1km long, it is best seen near Istanbul University, where the city has erected a marker explaining its significance. Worth checking out if you are in the area.
This connects Taksim area. If you get down in Aksaray tram walk down there are signs to Taksim by foot.

my favorite place in Istanbul
Many many old books. May find what you are looking for.
You can find old books there
Sohbeti hoş insanlar, ikram çaylar ve kitaplar. Ziyaret etmek için başka bir nedene ihtiyacınız mı var?

Orjinalina sadık kalınmış bir mekan

Moğolların Meryem'i Kilisesi

Kanlı Meryem Kilisesi olarak da adlandırılan bu tarihi yapı İstanbul'da görülmesi gereken yerlerden biri. Ancak diğer yorumcuların bazı fikirlerine katılmıyorum. Mesela bahçe son derece bakımsız, kilisenin içine girdiğinizde havasızlıktan kaynaklanan inanılmaz bir koku ile karşılaşıyorsunuz. Buda buradan sorumlu kişilerin görevlerini yerine getirmediklerini gösteriyor. Hiçte öyle size yardımcı ve cana yakın değiller. Hiç bir bilgilendirme yapmıyorlar, safece içeride fotoğraf çekmeyin uyarısında bulunuyorlar. Sizi içeri rica minnet alıyorlar. Herkezin bahsettiği ayazma ya ise inemiyorsunuz. Mutlaka bir rehber eşliğinde gitmenizi öneririm. Kilisenin hemen arkasında yer alan ve mimari görüntüsü ile hayranlık uyarından yapı ise "Kırmızı Mektep " .
Arkasında Albayrak Sokak'ta Bizans Blakhernai Saray kalıntıları var (vardı!). Yine aynı sokaktaki Hz. Ebubekir Gifari Cami bahçesinde Bizans yapı kalıntılarını görebilirsiniz

formatted_address: Silahtarağa, Silahtarağa Cd. 2/4, 34050 Eyüp/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Istanbul Dolphinarium

reviews.text: Dolphin show is great. The facility is well organized. A bit crowded when people go into stage. Trainers are good, and the show includes a sea lion, a walrus a white balooga whale and the dolphins of course. Muhteşem bir bina, tarihi önemi çok kıymetli bir mekan, Türkiye’nin önemli bir Üniversitesi, görülmeye değer.

1453’te dünya tarihinde yeni bir çağ başlamıştır. Bu tarihi dönemecin mekanı İstanbul’dur. İstanbul, kuzeyden güneye inen deniz yolunun ve doğudan batıya doğru giden karayolunun kesiştiği noktada yer almaktadır. Bu coğrafyaya doğal bir iç liman olan Haliç de eklenince ortaya tarih boyunca önemini kaybetmeyen bir şehir çıkmıştır.

Böylesine önemli bir coğrafyada yer alan İstanbul’u alan Fatih Sultan Mehmed, şehrin gelişmesi için hemen harekete geçer. Molla Gürani ve Molla Hüsrev gibi döneminin önde gelen hocalarından ders alarak kendini yetiştiren Fatih Sultan Mehmed, İstanbul’u yalnız devlet merkezi değil, aynı zamanda bilim ve kültür merkezi de yapmak ister.  

Dini bilimlerin yanı sıra fen bilimlerine de önem veren Fatih Sultan Mehmed’in davetiyle, Semerkad’dan Venedik’e, dünyanın farklı yerlerindeki sanat ve bilim adamları İstanbul’a gelmeye başlar. Süheyl Ünver, “Fatih Sultan Mehmed medreselerine müsbet ilimleri sokmakla büyük bir hamlenin başlangıcını yapmıştır” demektedir.

MEDRESE DÖNEMİ

Süheyl Ünver, İstanbul Üniversitesi’nin ilk olarak Zeyrek ve Ayasofya medreselerinde kurulduğunu ve 18 yıl boyunca bu mekanlarda eğitim verdiğini anlatmaktadır.

Prof. Dr. Fehameddin Başar: İstanbul Üniversitesi’nin kuruluşunu, 1453 yılında İstanbul’u fethine kadar götürmek mümkün. Çünkü Fatih Sultan Mehmet İstanbul’u fethettikten sonra bu şehri, bir ilim merkezi, bir kültür merkezi haline dönüştürmeyi de planlamıştı ve Osmanlı şehirlerindeki ilim adamlarını, müderrisleri İstanbul’a davet etmişti ve fetihten sonraki ilk Cuma günü, 1 Haziran 1453’te Ayasofya’da kılınan ilk Cuma namazında hocalarına, hocalara, hocaları saydığı âlimlere, müderrislere derhal eğitimin başlamasını emretmişti ve bunun üzerine fetihten hemen sonraki günlerde Ayasofya camiye dönüştürülünce, Ayasofya’nın kenarındaki keşiş odaları medreseye dönüştürülerek burada eğitim başlamıştı. Dolayısıyla İstanbul’da ilk yüksek öğretim, üniversitemizin de temelini oluşturan eğitim, Ayasofya’da ve hemen onun sonrasında da Zeyrek’te bulunan Pantokrator Kilisesi medreseye dönüştürülerek, bu iki medresede yüksek öğretim başlamıştı. İşte bu iki medrese eğitimi üniversitemizin temelini oluşturan medreselerdir.

Prof. Dr. Mahmut Ak: Ayasofya’da ilk cuma namazının kılınmasıyla itibaren hemen orada bir eğitim odası oluşturularak eğitime başlanmıştır. Zeyrek’teki eğitim kurumları yeni medrese grubunun yapılmasına kadar bu görevi üstlenmiştir. Nitekim Fatih Medreseleri’nin yapılmasıyla birlikte de aslında üniversitemizin temsil ettiği, Cumhuriyetimizin eğitim kurumlarına kadar uzanacak bir serüvende bu şekilde başlamış olmaktadır.

 Fatih Sultan Mehmet, fethin hemen ertesinde Zeyrek Mehmet Efendi’yi Pantokrator Manastırı’nda kurulan medreseye müderris tayin eder. Sonraki yıllarda bu medrese Zeyrek Medresesi, medresenin bulunduğu semt de Zeyrek olarak anılmaya başlanır. Fatih, zaman zaman Zeyrek Medresesi’ne giderek bizzat dersleri ve tartışmaları dinler.

Bina, Fatih Külliyesinin yapımına kadar medrese olarak kullanılır. Bina bugün Zeyrek Camii olarak hizmet vermeye devam ediyor.

We have found the castle by a chance - we saw it from the ferry when arriving to the Anadolu Kavaği. It took us about 20 min to walk there from the ferry terminal. You have to pass the Yoros restaurant on the slope.
Fantastic location is the main asset of the castle. The castle offers commanding views of the Bosporus Strait, third bridge and Black Sea. You can watch not just ships entering and departing Bosporus strait, but also enjoy lush hilly country - so different from the Istanbul's crowds.
The castle is not well-kept and access to the courtyard is prohibited. Pity.

reviews.text: It is a place worth visiting,whether you are orthodox christian or not. The history of this place,of people who have taken care of it,the details,and relics that are here are just stunning. You won't be sorry for visiting it.

A lovely oasis of calm in the middle of this chaotic city. If you are lucky you will get to meet or see the Patriarch Bartolomew. Forget the crowds at the Vatican, here you may have the whole complex to yourself.  The interior is awe inspiring from the icons to the incense and candles. Do not miss out on walking around the local neighborhood. There are jewels from all the Jewish, Christian and Islamic faiths found around every corner.

Worth a stop when you are in the area. We went in during a christening and it was interesting to witness the ceremony. Make sure to explore the area, very fun place and not as touristy as Sultanhemet or Taksim.

This is the second largest religious Byzantine building in Istanbul, after Hagia Sophia. It's built in 1118 originally with the name of Monastery of Pantocrator. formatted_address: Kemankeş Karamustafa Paşa, Kemeraltı Cd. No:50, 34425 Beyoğlu/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Kilic Ali Pasa Mosque

reviews.text: It is above medium sized mosque was built in 1580 by the famous Sinan engineer. It is indeed a beautiful piece of art and it has some attached service buildings such as a Hammam.

Commissioned by the Kilic Ali Pasha, an ambitious 16th century Italian privateer who converted to Islam, and was named Uluç Ali Reis. He rose up the ranks from slave to captain of his ship, later going on to become the Kapudan-i Derya (Grand Admiral) of the Ottoman navy. The name Kılıç (meaning sword) was conferred upon him on his appointment.

Rumours have it that when he announced he would endow a mosque, his rival, the Grand Vizier Rustem Pasha (who commissioned Rustem Pasha Mosque), said that, "Since he is the admiral, let him build his mosque on the sea." The ever-determined Kilic Ali Pasha simply had an artificial island built in the Bosphorus strait, and the mosque went on top of that.

It is one of the cleanest mosques in Istanbul.

It is one of the Great Architect, Mimar Sinan's works. It has a very interesting story of Captain Kilic Ali Pasha, captain of War Lepanto. The mosque is also known as Don Quixote Mosque because of the rumors about Cervantes(it is believed that he had worked in the construction, never proven though..) Right next to it, there are hamams and külliye (educational complex) which belong to the same Kilic Ali Paşa facility of the time.

A nice expression of Man and his Creator 's love...... One of the wonderful and beautiful monument and world's great heritage..... When human is not so much developed, the construction of such masterpiece is a really great example of human's determination

Beautiful and marvelous design!!!👌👌👌

reviews.text: I don't give bad reviews very often, but I've been here a couple times now, and I feel thst I can finally give this place a review it deserves. The second time here, I've noticed inflated prices, tourists accompanied by translators, and sellers quoting prices in dollars. This place just isn't the "antique market where you can buy treasures cheap" as peolle used to say. It's becoming another ruined tourist destination. It's sad to see it become this way.

formatted_address: Göztepe, Atatürk Cd. No:12, 34815 Beykoz/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Ford - Gürbaşlar Anadolu Hisarı Otomotiv

reviews.text: Best second hand autos...

Cam otomatiğinde yaşadığım arıza nedeniyle Ford Gürbaşlar'a gittim. Servis yetkilisi Şener bey ve müşteri hizmetlerindeki Gülşah hanım sorunla ilgilendi, kısa sürede problem giderildi. Kendilerine teşekkür ederim. Bu zamana kadar gittiğim en düzenli servis olduğunu söyleyebilirim. Bir sonraki bakıma da buraya gelmeyi planlıyorum. Tavsiye ederim.

Paramla rezil olduğum yer 0 km aracı burdan alındı bütün senelik bakımlarına burda girdi.. Motoru yandı yine bunlar onardı.(42000tl) indirimle 30000 falan ödedim. Bu esnada volant i bozdular. Kabul etmiyorlar. Allah yardımcıları olsun.

Bu yazdıklarım Ford Otosan ve Ford Gürbaşlar'ın gerçek yüzünü yansıtmaktadır. Kesinlikle her ikisi de satana kadar ilgi ve alaka sattıktan sonra her şey bitiyor. Yazıklar olsun size Ford Otosan genel müdürü h** y** bile bana cevap verememiştir. Ben İstanbul Anadolu Hisarı Gürbaşlar Ford'dan sıfır km bir araç aldım aracı satana kadar karşımda her türlü ilgilenenler araç daha 300 km'de baskı balata volan ve şanzıman ötmeye başladı. (yol yardım raporuna göre şanzıman ötüyor araç fabrikasyon hatalı değişimi gerekli bayii ise baskı balata volan ötüyor onları değişelim diyor) Sağ taraf tavan iç güneşlik kısmında kabarma var arka stoplar su alıyor araç kalkışlarda silkeleme yapıyor ayrıca Gürbaşlar bize teslim edilmeden önce sıfır km aracı arka taraf sağ kısımdan vurarak hasar vermiştir. Yine farklı bir servisin tespitine göre araç ön tampondan da hasar almıştır. Ayrıca 88 bin ödediğim araca 74 bin fatura kesilmiş olup ayıplı aracın değişimi için ne satıcı ve baş sorumlu olan Gürbaşlar Ford ne de Ford Otosan en ufak bir adım atmamaktadır ben tüm bu şikayetlerimi dile getirip Gürbaşlar'ın Ford sosyal medya hesaplarında haklı olarak sattıkları ayıplı araç için araç değişim istediğimde Gürbaşlar Ford bu ayıbının duyulmaması için sosyal medya hesaplarında beni engellemiştir. Yine il ticaret müdürlüğüne verdikleri yazıda kusurları kabul etmelerine rağmeh değişim yapılmadı Yine ilgili firmanın genel müdürü a** bey beni aramış o yorumları kaldır demiştir. Bende o zaman madem genel müdürsün ayıplı aracınıza sahip çıkıp değiştirin dedim sözde genel müdür olduğunu iddia eden bu şahıs buna yetkim yok dedi eğer kaldırmazsan sana ticari kazanç kaybıma neden olmaktan dava açacağım dedi. Ben de sorun yok dedim, ertesi gün avukatları beni aradı aracın durumunu anlattım abi benim bunlardan haberim yoktu dedi kapattı. Şaka gibi ama bu durum yaşandı ayrıca aracın koltuk kızak geçmesi isimli plastik bir parçası kırılmış olup bu parçayı Gürbaşlar'dan daha önce sipariş nedenim nedeni parasını ödeyip teslim almaya gittiğimde ilgili firmanın üst düzey bir yöneticisi hem bana karşı hem aileme karşı büyük bir saygısızlık yapmış ve size hizmet vermiyoruz siz internette hep bizi paylaşıyorsunuz aracınızı alın çıkın demiş olup Gürbaşlar bu sorunu internette paylaştım diye sözde üst yönetim olarak bir karar almışlar, araca hizmet vermeyeceklermiş zaten çok hizmet veriyordunuz ya... Gürbaşlar siz önce yaptığınızı temizleyin sıfır km araca anahtar vurmak istemek yerine değişim yapın. Gürbaşlar aracı sattıktan sonra asla ilgilenmiyor arkasında durmuyor Ford'da bu bayii hakkında gerekli işlemi yapamıyor.
Çok güzel oto servisi var. Arabama yapılan bakımdan memnun kaldım.

Suleiman the Magnificent, the tenth Ottoman sultan. He was the son of Yavuz Sultan Selim who was born in Hafsa Sultan on 27 April 1495 in Trabzon. He was raised from a young age with good manners and collections. When he was the governor of Manisa, his father Yavuz Sultan Selim died on September 22, 1520, 30 September 1520 was the throne. He personally participated in thirteen expeditions during his sultanate and these expeditions were successful.

This is the resting place of Sultan Suleiman I, commonly known as Suleiman the Magnificent in the West and Kanunî Sultan Süleyman (Ottoman Turkish: قانونى سلطان سليمان‎; "The Lawgiver Suleiman") in his realm, was the tenth and longest-reigning Sultan of the Ottoman Empire from 1520 until his death in 1566. Under his administration, the Ottoman state ruled over at least 25 million people.
It is located within the Sultan Suleiman Mosque's complex. Around its Tomb there is also a tomb of his wife and many other graves of his relatives and Pashas.

The resting place of Sultan Suleyman and some of his wives, sons and daughters. It is located in front of the mosque complex, within a cemetery, all sharing the same compound. reviews.text:
This is the rest place of three of the Sultan, Sultan II Mahmud, Sultan Abdul Aziz, Sultan II Abdul Hamid. 
Mahmud II (Ottoman Turkish: محمود ثانى‎ Mahmud-u s̠ānī, محمود عدلى Mahmud-u Âdlî; Turkish: İkinci Mahmut; 20 July 1785 – 1 July 1839) was the 30th Sultan of the Ottoman Empire from 1808 until his death in 1839.
Abdülaziz (Ottoman Turkish: عبد العزيز / `Abdü’l-`Azīz, Turkish: Abdülaziz; 8 February 1830 – 4 June 1876) was the 32nd Sultan of the Ottoman Empire and reigned between 25 June 1861 and 30 May 1876. He was the son of Sultan Mahmud II and succeeded his brother Abdulmejid I in 1861.
Abdul Hamid II (Ottoman Turkish: عبد الحميد ثانی‎, `Abdü’l-Ḥamīd-i sânî; Turkish: İkinci Abdülhamit; 21 September 1842 – 10 February 1918) was the 34th Sultan of the Ottoman Empire and the last Sultan to exert effective control over the fracturing state.
Three of Turkish Sultans and Caliphs's graves are here along with many princes and  pasha's.

formatted_address: Binbirdirek, Fatih Anıt Parkı, 34083 Fatih/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Yılanlı Sütun

reviews.text: This bronze column is located in the Hippodrome (open air museum). It is missing the head though. The ground level is raised due to changes to the infrastructure of the city.

The three-headed serpent column is located in the ancient hippodrome now called Sultanahmet Meydanı.  It was built to commemorate the Greeks who fought and defeated the Persian Empire at the Battle of Plataea (479 BC).

En. - Known as the Serpentine Column, it is a bronze column located inside the Hippodrome of Constantinople, modern Istanbul, Turkey. It is part of an ancient Greek sacrificial tripod, originally in Delphi and relocated to Constantinople by Constantine the Great in AD 324. It was built to commemorate the Greeks who fought and defeated the Persian Empire at the Battle of Plataea in 479 BC. The serpent heads remained intact until the end of the 17th century, its provenance is almost 2,500 years old. Together with its original golden tripod and cauldron (both long missing), it constituted a trophy, or offering reminding of a military victory, dedicated to Apollo at Delphi. This offering was made in 478 BC, several months after the defeat of the Persian army in the Battle of Plataea in 479 BC by those Greek city-states during the Greco-Persian Wars.

Very nice monument
Must see
Take photo with
And read information about it

Among the several historical monuments of the Sultanahmet square we came across the so-called serpent column. It is set, with other monuments up in the middle of the Hippodrome also dubbed the spina. The Serpent Column, known in the old days as the Tripod of Plataea, celebrated the victory of the Greeks over the Persians during the Persian Wars in the 5th century BC. It was moved from the Temple of Apollo at Delphi, and set in middle of the Hippodrome. The top was adorned with a golden bowl supported by three serpent heads. We don’t see the heads anymore; however some parts of the heads were recovered and are displayed at the Istanbul Archaeology Museum. In fact, they report that the serpent heads and top third of the column were destroyed in 1700. Nonetheless, it is a charming place to visit while in Istanbul. With or without a guide, just raise your head and breathe, all the history is in the air. Instagram @profnasr

Церковь находится во дворе, проход в который закрыт дверью. Поэтому нужно сначала найти её и позвонить в звонок. Нам дверь помогли отыскать местные. Пожилой мужчина на турецком объяснял, но мы поняли) 
Были тут в понедельник, людей не было вообще. Настоятели провели в храм, рассказали что и как делать с ключами. Сначала нужно выбрать желание(здоровье, удача, любовь, ребёнок и т.д.), затем приобрести за 20 лир набор из ключа, металической фигурки желания и свечи. После чего идём к иконе, водим по ней три раза фигуркой, крутим ключом три раза в любой скважине под иконой, умываемся и пьём воду внизу из святого источника, не забываем взять с собой бутылочку в дорогу. И в завершение ставим свечу в соседнем небольшом деревянном здании. Теперь ждём исполнения желания! Если оно сбудется, обязательно возвращаем ключ и фигурку в церковь. Говорят, что самые сильные дни - 1е число каждого месяца, особенно 1 января. В эти дни тут максимальное количество людей. Те, чьё желание исполнилось, будут угощать сладостями.

formatted_address: Şehit Muhtar, Cumhuriyet Anıtı, 34437 Beyoğlu/İstanbul, Turkey
