reviews.text: Proud to be there at one of the famous Landmarks of Awesome Istanbul.

Historical monument in the middle of taksim square. Designed by Italian sculptor Pietro Canonica and built in two and a half years with financial support from the population, it was unveiled by Dr. Hakkı Şinasi Pasha on August 8, 1928. The 11 m high monument portrays the founders of the Turkish Republic, with prominent depictions of Mustafa Kemal Atatürk, İsmet İnönüand Fevzi Çakmak. The monument has two sides: the side facing north depicts Atatürk in military uniform during the Turkish War of Independence, while the side facing south (towards İstiklal Avenue) has Atatürk and his comrades dressed in modern Western clothing; the former symbolizing his role as military commander-in-chief, and the latter symbolizing his role as statesman. Instagram @profnasr
It’s a must 😍

The Republic Monument is a notable monument located at Taksim Square in Istanbul, Turkey to commemorate the formation of the Turkish Republic in 1923. Built in two and half years.
Designed by Italian sculptor Pietro Canonica and built in two and a half years with financial support from the population, it was unveiled by Dr. Hakkı Şinasi Pasha on August 8, 1928. 
The 11 m (36 ft) high monument portrays the founders of the Turkish Republic, with prominent depictions of Mustafa Kemal Atatürk, İsmet İnönü and Fevzi Çakmak. The monument has two sides: the side facing north depicts Atatürk in military uniform during the Turkish War of Independence, while the side facing south (towards İstiklal Avenue) has Atatürk and his comrades dressed in modern Western clothing; the former symbolizing his role as military commander-in-chief, and the latter symbolizing his role as statesman.
Semyon Ivanovich Aralov, Ambassador of the Russian SFSR in Ankara during the Turkish War of Independence, is among the group of people behind Atatürk (his figure wears a cap and stands behind İsmet İnönü, on the southern facade of the monument). His presence in the monument, ordered by Atatürk, points out to the financial and military aid sent by Vladimir Lenin in 1920, during the Turkish War of Independence (1919–1922).
Republic square lies in the centre of Taksim Square it is made to commemorate the freedom fighters

Πύλη του Πολυάνδρου ή Πύλη του Μυρίανδρου ή Πύλη Χαρισίου - Edirne Kapı
Η πύλη, «δεύτερη των υπό του Κόλπου προς την Προποντίδα αριθμουμένη», σύμφωνα με το Σκαρλάτο Βυζάντιο, επί Βυζαντινής Αυτοκρατορίας ονομαζόταν Πύλη του Πολυάνδρου ή Πύλη του Μυρίανδρου και Πύλη Χαρισίου. Οι δύο πρώτες ονομασίες αποδίδονται στο πολυσύχναστο της τοποθεσίας της πύλης, η οποία βρισκόταν στη μέση οδό που οδηγούσε στο κέντρο της πόλης και άρα σε σημείο απ' όπου «μυριάδες» ανθρώπων περνούσαν καθημερινά. Ο Βυζάντιος δε θεωρεί έγκυρη την παρεμφερή εξήγηση του Κωδινού ότι η πύλη πήρε αυτή την ονομασία κατά τη διάρκεια της ανακαίνισης των τειχών από το Θεοδόσιο, από το πλήθος των συγκεντρωμένων εκεί αντιπάλων Βενετών και Πρασίνων, καθένας από τους οποίους προσπαθούσε να θέσει τη συγκεκριμένη πύλη υπό την προστασία του.

reviews.text: This is a great monument of victory for one of the greatest conquerors in history. He conquered the unbeatable Constantinople at 21 years of age which shows the great strategic ability and strong resolve of this young man. The mosque is an equally great example of genius engineering and it shows the magnificent contributions of this great man to culture and civilization.

The young conqueror (Mehmet II), a brilliant and successful statesman, was the most beloved sultan.
His dignity has made the Fatih Mosque a sacred place.
There are only those who come to visit this mosque from very distant parts of Anatolia and the Islamic World.
Foreign tourists don't come here much. They like colorful gaudy things.
Tourists, however, are far from capturing the peace that a true Turk and sincere Muslims can feel.
You will hear the feeling of this beautiful place that has given the justice and trust of Islam to everyone.

One of my favorite mosques in Istanbul! Very, very family friendly with areas for kids to play. Beautiful environment and shops around! Clean accessible bathroom. Not to mention the amazing knafa (Syrian/Turkish dessert) place, that is right outside one of the doors of the courtyard. There's always a line so you can't miss it!

reviews.text: Impressive and affecting place, real old power station be in used, but now clean and cozy. There are some cafes on the territory.

Very good museum for who is fond of engineering, well maintained equipment showing there like Turbines, Generator and steam Boiler as well as control room. Turbines with different types and power capacities that belong to a wide period of time. There is some other interesting things about electrical engineering or you can do some electrical experiments.
Really nice place and informative

It's an old power generation plant converted to a museum, has guided and un guided tours with interactive displays. It's informative technologically and historically. Takes about 50 minutes to an hour to go through. Has some experiments that are interesting for kids and adults. Coffe shops and food available close by.
They don't have enough information about the machines.

NEW MOSQUE HÜNKAR KASRI Hünkar Kasn, which is a part of Yeni Cami Külliye, is located in Historical Yarsmada. One of the most important works of classical Ottoman architecture, Yeni Mosque Hünkar Kasri'nin 17, yuzyila belongs to the rare china sedefkári, edimekáni and tung alki examples are found. In the vault door, the barley pine, the tiled stoneware, the walls of the tiled panels and the colored glass windows are regarded as rare breeding points. Some parts of the tiles are custom made to decorate. THE NEW MOSQUE HUNKAR PAVILION The New Mosque The new mosque is located in the middle of the 17th century. The entrance to the palace has a nice view of the walls, the walls and the walls are stained-glass windows. Some tiles and porcelain have been prepared and made for decoration.

reviews.text: This is a great monument of victory for one of the greatest conquerors in history. He conquered the unbeatable Constantinople at 21 years of age which shows the great strategic ability and strong resolve of this young man. The mosque is an equally great example of genius engineering and it shows the magnificent contributions of this great man to culture and civilization.

The young conqueror (Mehmet II), a brilliant and successful statesman, was the most beloved sultan.
His dignity has made the Fatih Mosque a sacred place.
There are only those who come to visit this mosque from very distant parts of Anatolia and the Islamic World.
Foreign tourists don't come here much. They like colorful gaudy things.
Tourists, however, are far from capturing the peace that a true Turk and sincere Muslims can feel.
You will hear the feeling of this beautiful place that has given the justice and trust of Islam to everyone.

One of my favorite mosques in Istanbul! Very, very family friendly with areas for kids to play. Beautiful environment and shops around! Clean accessible bathroom. formatted_address: Cankurtaran, Alemdar Cad., 34122 Fatih/İstanbul, Turkey

reviews.text: Lovely place.rich with architecture and history

Sarây-ı Cedîd (Yeni Saray) diye adlandırılan ve bugün yanlış olarak Topkapı Sarayı adıyla anılan büyük saray manzumesini çeviren Sûr-ı Sultânî’nin Divanyolu caddesine bakan köşesindeki burcun üstünde inşa edilmiştir. Sirkeci Hocapaşa’daki Aydınoğlu Dergâhı önünden yukarı kıvrılan surun Alay Köşkü yakınında tamamen Türk klasik mimarisi üslûbunda sivri kemerli Sokullu Mehmed Paşa Kapısı bulunmaktadır. Karşı tarafında ise XVIII. yüzyıldan beri sadâret makamı olan Bâbıâli’nin evvelce yalnız sadrazamların girip çıkmalarına mahsus ve şimdiki biçimini XIX. yüzyılın ilk yarısında alan geniş saçaklı girişi, Paşa Kapısı bulunmaktadır. Alay Köşkü’nün az ilerisinde bugün Gülhane Parkı’nın girişi olan ve Soğukçeşme Kapısı olarak adlandırılan kapının iki yanındaki yayvan kemerli girişler ise 1913’te Operatör Cemil Paşa’nın şehreminliği zamanında açılmıştır.

Alay Köşkü,  Bâb-ı Âli’nin karşısında, Gülhane Parkı’nın Soğukçeşme Kapısı’nın solunda, Topkapı Sarayı surlarının Alemdar Caddesi’ne bakan burçlarının üstünde yer almaktadır. Geçmişte köşkün şu andaki yerinde, Fatih Sultan Mehmet zamanında yapıldığı düşünülen aynı isimli ahşap bir köşk bulunduğu bilinmektedir. Köşkün pencere kemerlerinde bulunan tunç harfler ile yazılmış manzum kitabesinden mevcut köşkün, eski köşkün konumuna göre daha yüksek bir şekilde 1819 yılında Sultan II. Mahmut döneminde yaptırıldığı anlaşılmaktadır.

Alay Köşkü padişahların resmi geçit törenlerini izlemesi, asker ve halkı selamlaması amacıyla inşa edilmiştir. Bu nedenle köşkün bir diğer ismi de “Selam Köşkü”dür. İmparatorluk döneminde sefere çıkılmadan önce, askerler teçhizatları ile birlikte bir geçit töreni düzenler, padişah da onları bu köşkten izler ve selamlardı. Ayrıca, şehrin ￼esnaf ve tüccarlarının seyyar sayımının yapıldığı lonca alaylarını da padişah yine bu köşkten izlerdi. Lonca alaylarının sonuncusu 1769 yılında Sultan II. Mustafa zamanında yapılmıştır.

Alay Köşkü, ampir üslubu ile yapılmış üç katlı kagir bir yapıdır. Kesin bir kanıt olmamakla birlikte, mimari üslubu nedeniyle köşkün mimarının devrin gözde mimarlarını yetiştiren Balyan ailesinden Kirkor Amira Balyan olduğu düşünülmektedir. Köşkün ahşap olan dış cephesi mermer ile kaplanmıştır. Gülhane Parkı’na bakan iki kanatlı iki kapısı ile on dört adet penceresi bulunmaktadır. Köşkün pencere kemerleri, Hattat İzzet Molla tarafından yazılan yazılar ile pencereler ise demir parmaklıklarla süslüdür. Yapının üstünü örten kurşun kaplı külahın altında yer alan kubbenin içinde ve sofanın tavanında zengin kalem işi süslememeler bulunmaktadır. Köşkte, köşe burcu üzerine ￼oturtulmuş yuvarlak hünkâr salonu ile çeşitli büyüklüklerde hizmet odaları mevcuttur.

Alay Köşkü Osmanlı tarihindeki bir takım önemli olaylara da sahne olmuştur. Sultan IV. Mehmet döneminde, Halep valisi Vezir Haseki Mehmet Paşa yolsuzluk yaptığı iddiası ile İstanbul’a getirilerek, köşkün önünde divan katibi ve kethüdası ile birlikte idam edilmiştir. Alay Köşkü’nün yer aldığı bir diğer önemli tarihi olay ise Vakay-i Vakvakiye (Çınar Olayı)’dir. Girit kuşatmasını izleyen süreçte, maaşlarını alamadıkları ve paranın tağşiş edilmesi (değerinin düşürülmesi) ile zor duruma düştükleri iddiası ile yeniçeriler tarafından başlatılan isyan sonucu henüz on beş yaşında olan Sultan IV. Mehmet, isyancılar tarafından bir ayak divanına mecbur bırakılmıştır. İsyancıları Alay Köşkü’nde kabul eden padişah, isteklerinin ne olduğunu sorduğunda el kaldırarak söz alan Mehmet Ağa, ￼kendilerinin padişaha bağlı olduklarını ancak bir takım saray görevlilerinin kellelerini istediklerini söylemiştir.  Sultan IV. Mehmet isyancıları taleplerinden vazgeçirmeye çalışmışsa da başarılı olamamıştır. Bunun üzerine, padişahın emri ile aralarında Kızlarağası Behram Ağa, Kapuağası Ahmet ve İbrahim Ağaların da bulunduğu yaklaşık otuz kişinin cesedi isyancılara teslim edilmiştir. Cesetler, isyancılar tarafından At Meydanı’na götürülerek bir çınar ağacına asılmıştır. Bu ağacın, cehennemde bulunduğuna inanılan ve meyveleri insan kafası şeklinde olan Vakvak Ağacı’na benzetilmesi nedeniyle, olay Vakay-i Vakvakiye olarak adlandırılmıştır. Alay Köşkü’nü etkileyen bir başka olay ise; 1808 yılında Sadrazam Alemdar Mustafa Paşa döneminde çıkan bir yeniçeri ayaklanmasında teslim olmayı reddeden Alemdar Mustafa Paşa’nın konağını havaya uçurarak kendisi ile birlikte yüzlerce yeniçeriyi öldürdüğü patlamadır. Bu patlamanın etkisiyle Alay Köşkü de zarar görmüştür. Ayrıca bir takım ￼kaynaklarda, Sultan (Deli) İbrahim’in köşkü, yoldan geçen kişileri tatar yayı ile vurmak için hâkim bir yer olarak kullandığı da belirtilmektedir.

Yenileşme ve değişim hareketleri ile birlikte Dolmabahçe Sarayı’nın yapılması sonucunda, Alay Köşkü de geçit törenlerindeki yerini Dolmabahçe Sarayı içerisinde yer alan Pembe Köşk’e bırakmıştır. 1855’te İsviçreli mimar Fossati kardeşlerin projesi üzerine, Alay Köşkü ile Soğukçeşme Kapısı yanındaki burç arasında ve surun dışına bitişik olarak yapılan Telgr

Alay Köşkü, Gülhane, İstanbul, 1880

II. Mahmud tarafından 1819’da inşa ettirilen Alay Köşkü, padişahın geçit yapan alayları izleyebilmesi için Topkapı Sarayı’nın etrafını çevreleyen Sur-u Sultani’nin üstüne yaptırıldı. Mimar Krikor Amira Balyan tarafından tasarlandığı tahmin edilen yapı, günümüzde Ahmet Hamdi Tanpınar Edebiyat Müze Kütüphanesi olarak hizmet vermektedir.

Osmanlı döneminde padişahların halkı ve gecen alaylari izlemek icin kullandığı bu köşk, 2.mahmut döneminde şuan ki görünümüne kavuşmuş, günümüzde kütüphane olarak hizmet vermektedir. Cok guzel bir mimarisini vardir. Ücretsiz ziyaret edebilirsiniz ve içerisinde huzurla kitabınızi okuyabilirsiniz. Gulhane parkindan iceri girer girmez sola döndüğünüzde giriş kapisini görebilirsiniz.

The Gazi Atik Ali Pasha Mosque, in Turkish: Gazi Atik Ali Paşa Camii, is a 15th century Ottoman mosque located in the Çemberlitaş neighbourhood of the Fatih district in Istanbul, Turkey. Its construction was started under the orders of the future Grand Vizier Hadım Atik Ali Pasha in 1496 and was completed in 1497, during the reign of Sultan Bayezid II. The mosque is located near the entrance to the Kapalıçarşı (Grand Bazaar), the Column of Constantine, and the historical Nuruosmaniye Mosque.

Cihangir Cami’i (Mosque) is one of my favourites, with its elegant minarets and dome. Recently renovated, the calm, quiet beauty of the mosque is complemented by a small terraced garden, with fabulous views overlooking the Bosporus. Following the death of Süleiman the Magnificent’s son, Şehzade Cihangir (1531-1553) Mimar Sinan, the great Ottoman architect, was commissioned to build a wooden mosque on the site (1559), in memory of Şehzade Cihangir (and, possibly, his brother, Mehmet), hence giving rise to the neighbourhood’s (mahalle) name. The mosque suffered damage in many different fires, as it was wooden, with the latest rebuilding being under Abdülhamid II in 1889. Originally a smaller copy of Sinan’s Mihrimah Sultan mosque in Edirne, the current square plan, single-dome retains the signature feature of the great architect’s work, being filled with light through large windows, though the original decoration and much else is gone. The associated medresse (religious school) has also long since disappeared under mid-20th century residential development. Because of its location, Cihangir Cami’i is one of the most visible landmarks on the heights of Pera, especially from the Bosporus.

This small mosque was originally built in wood in 1559 for the hunchbacked son of Roxelana and Süleiman the Magnificent, who died of grief after his brother Şehzade Mehmed’s early death at the age of 22. The current mosque dates from 1889 and, unfortunately, is no longer wooden.

formatted_address: Mimar Sinan, 34664 Üsküdar/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Vâlide-İ Cedid Camii

reviews.text: Beautiful ,historic,  amazing energy.
LP

Üsküdar’da, Hakimiyeti Miliye Caddesi, Balaban Caddesi ve İmam Nasır Sokak’ın arasında Valide-i Cedid Cami Külliyesi içerisinde bulunan Valide-i Cedid Cami, 1708-1711 yıllarında Sultan IV. Mehmed’in eşi, Sultan III. Ahmed’in annesi Emetullah Râbia Gülnûş Sultan tarafından yaptırılmıştır.Mimarı Kayserili Mehmed Ağa’dır.
Cami ve revaklı avlusu, oldukça büyük dış avlunun ortasındadır. Zeminden yükseltilmiş olan caminin revaklı avlusuna, eşiğine 9-10 basamaklı merdivenlerle çıkılan, üzerleri sivri alınlıklı üç kapıdan girilmektedir. Alınlıklarında Hezarfen Mehmed Efendi’nin hattı ile yazılmış ayetler bulunmaktadır. Küçük kubbelerle örtülü revaklarla kuşatılan avlunun merkezinde yer alan şadırvan sekizgen planlıdır. Şadırvanın köşeleri sütunlarla, yüzleri ise itinalı bir işçilik gösteren taş süslemelerle değerlendirilmiştir. Üst kısımda dolanan, manzum metni Osmanzâde Ahmed Tâib Efendi’ye ait kitabeden şadırvanın 1711 yılında tamamlandığı anlaşılmaktadır.
Caminin dış kurgusu, piramidal görünümlü klasik dönem örneklerinden farklı şekilde kademeler halinde yükselen dikey bir gelişim gösterir. Dış kütlede dikkati çeken en önemli ayrıntılar ise türünün ilk örneklerinden sayılan kuş evleridir. Oldukça zarif tasarlanmış bu detaylar Osmanlı’daki hayvan sevgisinin güzel örneklerindendir.
Camiye girişi sağlayan yüksek taçkapısı, mermer taş işçiliğinin ihtişamlı bir örneğidir. Kapının üst kısmında Tâib Ahmed Efendi’nin yazmış olduğu, 12 satır halinde ve her satırda dört mısra olmak üzere kırk sekiz mısralı 1122 (1710) tarihli kitabe bulunmaktadır. Taçkapının önündeki, son cemaat yeri, diğer avlu kanatlarına göre daha derin, büyük ve yüksek tutulmuş olup, ortası ve iki yanı aynalı çapraz tonoz, araları da birer kubbe olmak üzere, beş gözlü olarak düzenlenmiştir. Dört mermer sütunun taşıdığı son cemaat yerinde iki mihrap, alt ve üstte dörder pencere bulunur. Ayrıca burada kesme taş konsollar üzerine oturtulmuş bir mükebbire vardır. Son cemaat yerinin uçlarında bulunan tamamı muntazam kesme taştan yapılan 56 metre yüksekliğinde klasik tarzdaki iki şerefeli iki minaresi vardır. Caminin taçkapısından başka doğuda ve batıda birer giriş kapısı daha bulunmaktadır.
Caminin harim kısmı kareye yakın plana sahiptir. Sekizgen kurgulu taşıyıcı sistemle iri fil ayakların taşıdığı kemerlere oturtulan merkezi kubbenin dört köşesinde, çeyrek kubbeler yer alır. Bu düzenlemenin iki yanı, ortalarda birer aynalı çapraz tonoz, köşelerde de dört küçük kubbe ile derinleştirilmiş olup ağırlıklar doğu ve batıdaki dört serbest paye ile kuzey ve kıble yönünde de dört duvar payesine oturtulmuştur. Üç yanı dolanan iç mahfillere, taçkapıdan girildikten sonra iki yanda yer alan payeler içindeki birer merdivenle çıkılmaktadır. Klasik üslupta bir minbere sahip olan caminin mermer mihrabı abidevi bir örnektir. Kubbe eteğinde dolanan mukarnaslı friz dikkati çeken bir başka süsleme unsurudur. Harimde en dikkat çekici süslemeler ise, mihrabın sol tarafında yer alan konsollar üzerine oturan bir balkon şeklinde tasarlanmış hünkar mahfilinde görülür. Mahfil buradan bir kapı ile hünkar kasrına bağlanır.
Birçok tamirle günümüze kadar ulaşan bu cami; Yeni Valide Cami ve Gülnuş Valide Sultan Cami olarak da bilinmektedir.

Yeni Valide Camii; İstanbul Üsküdar sahilindeki meydanın güneyinde Hakimiyeti Milliye caddesi ile Balaban iskelesi sokağının kesiştiği noktada 1708- 1710 yıllarında Sultan II. Mustafa ve Sultan III. Ahmet'in annesi Emetullah Rabia Gülnuş Sultan tarafından Lale Devri baş mimarı Kayserili Mehmet Ağa’ya inşa ettirilmiştir.
CAMİNİN BANİSİ:
Haseki Emetullah Rabia Gülnuş Valide Sultan, 1647 yılında doğmuştur. Osmanlı döneminde Valide Sultan olup 2 ayrı padişahın annesidir. Sultan II. Mustafa ve Sultan III. Ahmet ve Sultan IV. Mehmet'ın eşiydi. Emetullah Rabia Gülnuş, 1647 yılında Girit'te doğdu. Babasının adı Retimo Verzizzi ve doğduğu zamanki ismi Eugenia Voria idi. 1695 yılında oğlu II. Mustafa'nın tahta çıkması üzerine Valide Sultan oldu. Devlet işlerine karışmadı ama Sultan II. Mustafa'nın tahtan indirilip yerine diğer oğlu Sultan III. Ahmet'in geçirilmesinde onayı alındı. Toplam 20 yıl Valide Sultan kaldıktan sonra 1715 yılında oğlu Sultan III. Ahmet'in saltanatı sırasında Edirne'de öldü. Ölümünden sonra Lale Devri başlamıştır. Vefatından önce, 1708'de yaptırdığı Üsküdar'daki Yeni Valide Camii'nin yanındaki üstü açık türbesine gömüldü.
Ezanlari  Karşısındaki Mihrimah sultan camii ile karşılıklı okuyorlar muhteşem bi ahenk oluyor

formatted_address: Anadolu Hisarı, Körfez Cd., 34810 Beykoz/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Anatolian Fortress

reviews.text:
Stunning sights, and a very nice place to walk.  Situated in a nice neighbourhood on the Bosphorus, with tons of nice restaurants and shops.

Also there are quite a few ferries to take to and from the location so driving is not a must.

I enjoyed a lovely evening there, and I would highly recommend this place day or night.
There are small coffees, where you can enjoy a cup of hot beverage or refresh yourself with a cold one near the Goksu River with a view and a peaceful mind.
Build on the era of Ottoman Castle, I recommend to visit this castle during your trip to Istanbul

Anadoluhisarı (English: Anatolian Castle), known historically as Güzelce Hisar ("the Beauteous Castle]) is a medieval fortresslocated in Istanbul, Turkey on the Anatolian(Asian) side of the Bosporus. The complex is the oldest surviving Turkish architectural structure built in Istanbul, and further gives its name to the neighborhood around it in the city's Beykoz district.
Anadoluhisarı was built between 1393 and 1394 on the commission of the OttomanSultan Bayezid I, as part of his preparations for a siege on the then-Byzantine city of Constantinople, the naval blockade of which took place in 1395 under Bayezid's orders.

Constructed on an area of 7,000 square metres (1.7 acres), the fortress is situated at the narrowmost point of the Bosporus, where the strait is a mere 660 meters (2,170 ft) wide. The site is bound by Göksu (Ancient Greek: Aretòs) creek to the south, and was previously home to the ruins of a Roman temple dedicated to Uranus.[2] Erected primarily as a watch fort, the citadel has a 25 meters (82 ft) tall, quadratic main tower within the walls of an irregular pentagon, with five watchtowers at the corners.

After Bayezid's campaign was first interrupted by the Crusade of Nicopolis, and then the Battle of Ankara, an 11-year period of turmoiltook hold of the Ottomans, which ended with the ascent of Mehmed I to the throne. His grandson, Sultan Mehmed II reinforced the fortress with a two-meter-thick wall and three additional watchtowers, and added further extensions, including a warehouse and living quarters. As part of his plans to launch a renewed military campaign to conquer Constantinople, Mehmed II further built a sister structure to Anadoluhisarı across the Bosphorus called Rumelihisarı, and the two fortresses worked in tandem in 1453 to throttle all maritime traffic along the Bosphorus, thus helping the Ottomans achieve their goal of making the city of Constantinople (later renamed Istanbul) their new imperial capital.

After the Ottoman conquest of the city, Anadoluhisarı served as a customs house and military prison, and after several centuries, fell into disrepair.

After the fall of the Ottomans and the 1923 establishment of the Republic of Turkey, the newly-created Turkish Ministry of Culturetended to and ultimately restored the site in 1991 - 1993. Today, Anadoluhisarı lends a picturesque appearance to its corner of the Bosphorus alongside the timber yalı homes that define the neighborhood, and functions as a historical site, although it is not open to the public.
Dont miss out on it's streets located right above, a little steep to walk but worth climbing... You'll love it.

formatted_address: Sultan Ahmet, Ayasofya Meydanı, 34122 Fatih/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Hagia Sophia Museum

reviews.text: In my opinion, this is the most impressive building in the world. Its age and size are spectacular. If you have no interest in churches or mosques, you still ought to come here. To stand where the emperors of Rome once stood is a truly humbling experience. Come at 9-10am if you can; it gets much busier shortly after that.

The famous basilica-come-mosque-come-museum. Ancient as the city itself, it is the main attraction here. 
There were some restorations around the main hall so we could not see 100% of the museum. However, the building is wonderful and you can smell the history there.
Plan 2 hours for the museum.

Any tourist will appreciate the beauty and the history of this place. A true must have. This church is so dramatic in its size that even during the busiest day you'll not feel cramped inside.  Imagine a 1000 years ago, what it was like to build such a masterpiece in a city with merely 200,000 people.

An orthodox will have a nostalgic pain deep in their heart of the times passed standing in this holy place.

One of my favourite places in the world. There is so much history and energy in the air. This was my 3rd time visiting this place, unfortunately there was some renovations going on , so the left side of the interior was covered in scaffolding. If you only have a limited time in Istanbul then this place is No.1 on the list of sites to see. Rich in history and meaning, this site will not fail to amaze you.

This is such a beautiful place, they are restoring it so one side of the big mosque is closed off with a scaffolding. I would definitely recommend anybody wish coming to Istanbul the police check this place out. There are wonderful art Works wonderful history and a lot of great things to see in this mosque. There are tour guides to walk around the mosque and you can get a earpiece to tell you every place in the mosque it is definitely worth the money if you would like to get it to a guy to tour you around the mosque. Please be careful when going to the Blue Mosque as it will be under construction for the rest of 2019.

formatted_address: Vişnezade, Dolmabahçe Cd., 34357 Beşiktaş/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Dolmabahçe Palace

reviews.text:
This is magnificent. It's a shame you're not allowed to take pictures. Many do anyway, but in the more opulent areas, there are guides yelling 'no photo' at everyone. It's not really temperature controlled- we went on an 85F day and inside it was close to 80F and oppressively hot inside.

They do limit ticket sales, so it's best to go early on busier days.

A very well organized museum walk through. The halls and rooms are simply fabulous and give you a sneak peek in the lives of Ottoman rulers. The only drawback, you cannot click pictures.
Entry is 60 Lira for Main Palace and additional amounts are charged if you want to visit other areas.

Classic historical place with the great photo shoot spots. Apart of its story behind and magnificent design from inside and outside of the buildings, you also can enjoy great cup of Turkish coffee with amazing sea view. You definitely need around 4 hours to manage to see everything in there, so be prepared with comfortable shoes, classic outfits and camera for the outside shooting.

It was awesome! I took the free audio guided tour. Highly recommend it. It was very helpful and informative. All directions are clearly defined so you don't get confused where to go next.
The place is also very beautiful on the inside. No picture can do justice to the art on the ceilings, the furniture and paintings. It is definitely a must see!

Extravagant palace of the Sultan - be ready to walk,  the grounds are extensive.  Majestic rooms, ornately decorated.  The palace is on the water,  but gates keep you from enjoying exposure to it.  Plan for about a 45 min wait to enter, and at least 2 hours to cover all areas.  Note that the art gallery is a separate entrance with a fee.

formatted_address: Binbirdirek, Sultan Ahmet Parkı No:2, 34122 Fatih/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Sultanahmet Square

reviews.text:
I love the atmosphere day and night. Families gathered together making picnic, playing,  laughing,  buses going everywhere and trams as well. You have cash points and the tourist police 24/7. You can snack on some sweetcorn (5TL) or chestnuts (10TL to 30 TL) which are delicious.  As you sit down to watch your environment,  people selling water(1TL), tea or coffee will offer everyone for 3TL. One evening  as I was sitting on a bench drinking tea, I was approached by a 25 year old man, he started to talk very respectfully so I didn't mind a conversation until he started to flirt. Perfect if that is what you are looking for. 
I have seen some Turkish guys pretending to be Spanish which I am, to a Korean tourist trying to take him for drinks.  It was a bit strange and I would be careful.  If you have any problems,  talk to the police, present all over the square.
Amazing restaurants offering homemade Turkish food for around 32TL (food, drink and bread). The restaurant is called Can. Other similar ones along the tram line.

Nice historical place. But beware people talking to you. They looked so nice and friendly but they always want to get something from you or make you pay something. It's a shame really. Because you would not dare to talk to anyone. And some people may genuinely nice

Great place to relax during sightseeing. always vendors selling simit and corn. Cross the street to the west and buy some ice cream, then cross back and enjoy it on a bench while watching the people from all over the world. There are great views here, between ayasofia mosque and the blue mosque.
The atmosphere was like nothing else. The place is loaded with historical buildings and can easily take all day walking, exploring and sightseeing.
The place is full of history and really well organized. You can spend two or three days visiting it's surroundings alone.

formatted_address: Süleymaniye Mah, Prof. Sıddık Sami Onar Cd. No:1, 34116 Fatih/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Suleymaniye Mosque

reviews.text:
Definately one of the Istanbul highlights. Exceptionally well maintained (doesn't look it's 450 years!) And set in lovely gardens.

Easy to access with great views of the water as well.

Free to enter.

Absolutely incredible structure that left me in awe. It was certainly less crowded than the more popular Hagia Sofia and blue mosque, but I went later in the day around 1830. Visitors were allowed and clothing was offered at the door. If you're traveling to Istanbul, don't miss this beauty!

Suleymaniye Mosque is one of the oldest mosques in Istanbul. It is located on top of a hill with a beautiful view over the city and the Bosphorus. The construction and architecture of the mosque are fascinating. So much attention to details in every piece of the building. Open for free for the public. Modest dress code is recommended. Definitely worth visiting.

Another one of the grandest structures in Istanbul with so much of history attached to it. The best way to go there is to walk up. There are specific entrances for visitors and at the time of prayers the mosque is closed for visitors. 
You need to cover your head and your legs while going in.

A great experience as there was not much of a crowd as compared to the Blue Mosque. Also, volunteers present helped answer some of the questions which I have about the mosque and its unique at architectural style distinct from the mosques often seen in Southeast Asia.

formatted_address: Cankurtaran, 34122 Fatih/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Topkapi Palace Museum

reviews.text: A great place to visit, rich in history of Islam and also includes souvenirs of most of the prophets of Islam and Christianity. Also it is well maintained and coordinated. To avoid the rush the best time to visit is in March April

Topkapi Palace is marvelous. It is a must-see during the visit to Istanbul.
Plan to have more than 5 hours inside as they close by 8pm. We started at 4 and felt as if we just scratched the surface by 7:45!
Start from the right and make your way through the kitchen ( we spent 90 minutes there alone!) And go deeper until you see everything.
I highly recommend this visit. My family and I enjoyed our time. There is a mosque to pray if you want.

Located just around the corner to Aya Sophia. Has good access for wheelchair users. It's best to go in the morning as the ticket line can go all the way to the entrance. So many historical and beautiful things to see. Will take a good 4-5 hours to be able to see everything. There are a few areas where photography is not allowed. Security guards are located in each area. Overall worth the money. Some sections are barred off due to refurbishment. However the main areas such as the Prophet SAW artifacts are open to see.

It was very beautiful and you will stay there at least for 3-4 hours. So many different things to visit. It’s better to come early because many people visit that place and you will have long queue. A place to visit in Istanbul.

One of the best places that I have ever visited. The place houses so many things of historical importance and gives a fair idea of the grandeur of Ottoman Empire. And the Holy Relics of Islam that are here have no parallels in the world. For a Muslim things get really overwhelming in the chamber of Holy Relics

Istanbul is a very nice city especially Bosfor and its restaurants

formatted_address: Sultan Ahmet, Atmeydanı Cd. No:7, 34122 Fatih/İstanbul, Turkey
name: The Blue Mosque

reviews.text: Magnificent mosque!! This mosque is a must-see for any tourist. One of the finest architectural mosque buildings in the world. Unfortunately it was under heavy construction and renovation that blocked a lot of the beautiful walls. It’s also called the Blue Mosque due to the blue color of the countless ceramic tiles that make the interior really gorgeous. Women have to cover their head and hands, if you didn’t bring a cover with you there’s a cabin at the entrance of the mosque that provides head covers and skirts free of charge! Shoes have to be taken off too, plastic bags are also provided for free so you can carry your shoes with you. It’s very charming... words can’t describe it!

Historical architecture, beautiful surrounding. Free to access the building no entry fee. 

There is a dress code in place, no revealing clothes allowed if you're planning to enter the mosque, However, there is a booth inside the compound that gives out costumes to cover yourself which is also free.

It's always full of tourists taking pictures and picnicking on the mosque grounds, very beautiful at nights too.

 I should say it's very safe always police at presence, we never came across any problems while we were there.

It's one of those must see places.

This was a very pleasant experience, there is some renovation taking place that obscured your view of the amazing ceiling once inside.

It was disappointing seeing other tourist not being respectful of the nature of the building (uncovering hair once inside, a few not covering their legs and one trying to put plastic bags on her feet). 

It was good that head scarfs and leggings were provided.

The building itself is very impressive but so are the grounds.

Do you research, be respectful this is a place of worship after all.

It was great to visit the Sultan Ahmed mosque and feel the magnificence when seeing this great Islamic site. The mosque is large enough to host thousands of worshipers and part of it for tourists to enjoy the place. There are rules tourists have to follow when visiting the mosque, like taking off shoes (you will be having a plastic bag to put shoes in while you are inside the mosque),  also not shorts allowed for men, and women should dress decently (the will be given a scarf to cover their hair or shoulders). The mosque is surrounded by other monuments, shops and restaurants.

Beautiful mosque with impressive architecture, it's currently undergoing renovation and therefore has many parts of the building covered up. Tourists who are planning to visit will have to observe the rules of visiting a mosque, long pants for men and headscarf for ladies, you'll be given a plastic bag to remove and carry your shoes. Headscarves are available for ladies, but it's best to bring your own. Entry is free but you can make a donation to the mosque at the exit.

formatted_address: Piri Paşa, Hasköy Cd. No:5 D:No:5, 34445 Beyoğlu/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Rahmi M. Koç Museum

reviews.text: The museum is so big and contains so many exhibits it took us several hours to move around and we it wasn't enough to see all items. It's by far the most wonderful museum we visited in Istanbul. It contains all one can imagine of equipment and transport machines as well as models of Turkish houses over history. There's also a part of scientific experiments for children to use their heads and hands. You can also enjoy a train ride, a vessel or a submarine tour on weekends (that's Saturdays and Sundays), but there's an age limit for submarine tour ( 7 as I remember). the museums located on both sides of the main street, so don't miss any of part of it.

This is a brilliant museum with lots of exhibits including cars, trains, aeroplanes and boats. It is great for the children as there are vehicles that can be viewed as well as a mathematical problems room with lots of puzzles to solve. We have visited a few times and still haven't seen all of it.

Amazing, a must see place in İstanbul. So huge you need hours but worth it. Tickets are cheap, very clean toilets every where if you have kids. Restorant and break area among old cars and aircrafts. Must see the submarine, but it comes under a different ticket.
You may also donate to assist preserve the museum if you want.
Very high quality museum. Many pieces to see and to do. A clear recommendation. There is discount for the museum card. Also inform yourself about the small guided tours you may book.

The place is perfect to go with family and friends. It has cars. Boats. Train and planes. And kids games too. The view was amazing and the atmosphere is warm.. Fees for students is 7 lira.. Very cheap

formatted_address: Reşitpaşa, Emirgan Sk., 34467 Sarıyer/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Emirgan Park

reviews.text: Very big park i couldb't finish it . We were there during the spring vacation and the park was filled with the tulip flowers because it was the tulip festival in Istanbul. I brought my mother with me she enjoyed a lot but the problem was that my mom can't walk or stand for a long time so i had to bring her a wheelchair which was very difficult to push uphill. Close to the entrance of the park u can find very nice cafes

It is incredible park, families and kids can spend whole day enjoying their moment, a lot of activities can be done. You can kook and do BBq, the most beautiful is the sea view from the park, you can see Istanbul bridge which will take you to feel peace of mind. I am strongly recommended this place, don't miss the chance to go over there while visiting Istanbul

Nice and big park open for the public all day long. Worth visiting during spring because it usually gets filled with tulips. The downside is that the park is not clean. Unfortunately, some people don't clean after themselves. I hope there would be some kind of penalty for littering.

Perfect place for relaxation. You can eat at the Yellow Mansion which is on the opposite side of the Pink Mansion. There are many places where you can sit and take photos with friends and family. Entrance fee if you want to enter the park in car is 10 TL. Overall it is the place to spend time with your family.

This park was in my trip design created by Tripster. I have visited here during Tulip season in Istanbul and got fascinated by the beauty of various tulips. Learned the best spots from my travel designer and took great photos. Nice and big park open for the public all day long. Worth visiting during spring because it usually gets filled with tulips.

formatted_address: Merkez Mh, Cami Kebir Sk. No:1, 34050 Eyüp/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Eyüp Sultan Mosque

reviews.text: What a nice area. Small part of Western Europe in the city. Drastically different to most of tourist placed.
I like the atmosphere of the place. It is always festive and joyful. There is a cute little market place with souvenirs and Pier Loti cafe with fantastic views on the Haliç nearby.
Love this place and Shrine or Hazrat Ayub Ansari. Manage and good environment. Prophet Muhammad's beard hair is also preserve there. Love to feed pigeons out side of mosque
Excellent and important place to visit. The cafe at the top of the hill is excellent. You can also talked the cable car to the top with your Istanbul kart.

Must visit whilst in Istanbul. The great Companion and Relative of the Prophet Muhammad ﷺ.full of Barakah, peace and tranquility. The surrounding shops, community, buzz and people are amazing. 
Visiting the tomb of Abu Ayub Sultan is an outstanding experience. He was the friend of prophet Mohammad peace be upon him !

formatted_address: Alemdar, Yerebatan Cd. 1/3, 34110 Fatih/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Basilica Cistern

reviews.text:
Fantastic attraction that is well worth the visit. This spacious Roman built cistern shows off impressive Roman engineering. There are two large cistern rooms that are accessible through a tastefully lit walk way. The cistern is also lit along each column without the lighting being too strong so you get a great feel for the space.

At the end of the second room, there is a massive Medusa embellished column, that's worth going all the way for. Information boards tell you the history and point out details along the way.

It's a beautiful space.

Note that entry is not covered by the museum card, but there is a flat entry charge.

One of the most magical places I have ever seen. Visited it several times and every time it took my breath away. By design a pure engineering structure (water cistern for the Eastern Roman capital of Constantinople) has an immense beauty intensified by the perfectly managed lighting and mirroring of the light on the surface of the water. Worth every lira of the admission costs. Try to keep quiet in order not to spoil the experience for others.

A great and an unusual attraction to visit while in Istanbul. It is fascinating to see such constructions were built for hundreds of years ago. Perfect for a hot summer day. It is not always filled with water but still worth visiting even if it was empty. Entrance costs 10TL per person. Recommended.
Was very cool, nice and different. A good place to escape the heat. The Medusa heads are cool. It was 20 lira to get in so wasn't too expensive. You don't need long in there.

While often overcrowded and congested the Basilica Cistern offers a beautiful insight into some lost history in the heard of Istanbul. Visible damage caused by building on-top of the lost cistern can be seen in cracks in the columns and pathced holes in the ceiling of the area. An ultimately beautiful sight to take in and a perfect place to come during the hotter parts of the day. Take your time and explore each column individually, read the signs and take it all in.

formatted_address: Beyazıt, Kalpakçılar Cd. No:22, 34126 Fatih/İstanbul, Turkey
name: Grand Bazaar

reviews.text: Grand Bazaar is made up of several different types of markets. You'll have clothing, spices, housewares and jewellery to name a few. Each market has their own little section in the bazaar. Some of it is housed indoors like a small mall while others will be outside. If you're one for negotiating don't hesitate as it's common. They also have food throughout the bazaar mainly around the outskirts of the market.

A superb market area with history and character. However, beware shop sellers are like vultures with a sweet face and smile. Really , they overcharge as prices are highly inflated compared to other sites and places. All items including, footwear, leather goods, bags and Jewellery, watches, etc can be found elsewhere within Istanbul, so haggle down to less than half the asking price or you will be definitely paying above the odds! But, all in all, you will need to allow a day or two or even more to properly explore shop and enjoy the experience. Be sure to explore the shopping around the edges of the market as they provide a better price overall. Just relax and enjoy the Grand Bazar ottoman experience.

It was super crowded and air conditioned in only some places. The prices were not as low as I had hoped even when calculating/converting the Turkish Lira to US dollar. I did make some purchases, e.g. bought a 100% cotton white bathrobe for 70 TL, which is about $12. It wasn't your typical terry sort of material, it was the thin, waffle-stitched sort - less bulky and more absorbent. That was a great deal! I bought 8 pot/pan decorated coasters as souvenirs - look around until you find the merchants that sell them for 10 TL - there are some selling them for 15 and 20 TL.

As it name suggests ,it is a great experience,with the variety of things sold there,it surely a tourist delight. The coated nuts and ceramic plates etc were amazing. You can wander about and pick up anything to.take back home. I could pick up something for all my loved ones back home. The atmosphere was electrifying. Each seller trying his best to sell his wares. Of course one had to bargain a lot.

Great experience! A must visit if you are in Istanbul. We went there three times during our visit to Istanbul and had a splendid day each time! Make sure to bargain before you make a deal, always start at a third of the asking price! They have a wide variety of items. You can pretty much buy anything here, from jewellery to souvenirs to leather stuff to delicious food.
